It is not a sufficient objection that the answer to an interrogatory will determine a substantial issue in the proceeding.
On an application under rule 8.36 in respect of an interrogatory, a Judge may—
require the applicant to specify on what grounds the applicant objects to answer that interrogatory; and
determine the sufficiency of the objection.
If the Judge determines that the objection is not sufficient, the application is not entitled to object to answer the interrogatory.

prov.cf: 1908 No 89 Schedule 2 r 8.7 prior to 1 February 2012

history.history-note: Schedule 2 rule 8.40: replaced, on 1 February 2012, by rule 4 of the High Court Amendment Rules (No 2) 2011 (SR 2011/351).

prov.heading: Who may swear affidavit verifying statement in answer to interrogatories

para.text: An affidavit verifying a statement of a party in answer to interrogatories may be made as follows:
by the person required to make the statement:

if the person required to make the statement is a minor (other than a minor to whom rule 4.31(2) applies) or is an incapacitated person within the meaning of rule 4.29, by the person's litigation guardian:

if the person required to make the statement is a corporation or a body of persons empowered by law to sue or to be sued (whether in the name of the body or in the name of the holder of a registry), by a person who meets the requirements of rule 9.82:

if the person required to make the statement is the Crown, or an officer of the Crown who sues or is sued in an official capacity, or as representing a government department, by an officer of the Crown.
Despite subclause (1), if paragraph (c) or (d) of that subclause applies, and if the affidavit is to be filed and served in accordance with an order, a Judge may—
specify by name or otherwise the person who has to make the affidavit; or
specify by description or otherwise a group or class of persons, any 1 of whom may make the affidavit.

prov.cf: 1908 No 89 Schedule 2 r 8.8 prior to 1 February 2012

history.history-note: Schedule 2 rule 8.41: replaced, on 1 February 2012, by rule 4 of the High Court Amendment Rules (No 2) 2011 (SR 2011/351).

prov.heading: Insufficient answer

para.text: If a party fails to answer an interrogatory sufficiently, a Judge may, in addition to acting under rule 7.48,—
if the party has made an insufficient answer, order the party to make a further answer verified by affidavit in accordance with rule 8.38; or
order the party, or any of the persons mentioned in rule 8.41(1)﻿(b) to (d), as the case requires, to attend to be orally examined.

prov.cf: 1908 No 89 Schedule 2 r 8.9 prior to 1 February 2012

history.history-note: Schedule 2 rule 8.42: replaced, on 1 February 2012, by rule 4 of the High Court Amendment Rules (No 2) 2011 (SR 2011/351).

prov.heading: Incorrect answer to be amended

para.text: If, by reason of a change of circumstances or an error or omission, a statement filed in response to a notice given or order made under rule 8.34, 8.38, or 8.42 appears to the party who filed it or on whose behalf it was filed to be defective or erroneous, that party must promptly file and serve a further statement that corrects or supplements the original statement.
If the original statement was verified, the further statement must also be verified.

prov.cf: 1908 No 89 Schedule 2 r 8.10 prior to 1 February 2012

history.history-note: Schedule 2 rule 8.43: inserted, on 1 February 2012, by rule 4 of the High Court Amendment Rules (No 2) 2011 (SR 2011/351).

prov.heading: Answers as evidence

para.text: A party may give in evidence—
1 or more answers to interrogatories without giving the others:
part of an answer to an interrogatory without giving the whole of the answer.

If a party proposes to give in evidence an answer (or part of an answer) to an interrogatory (answer A), the Judge may look at the other answers, and if the Judge considers that answer A is so connected with another answer (answer B) that answer A ought not to be received without answer B, the Judge may refuse to receive answer A unless answer B is also given in evidence.

prov.cf: 1908 No 89 Schedule 2 r 8.11 prior to 1 February 2012

history.history-note: Schedule 2 rule 8.44: inserted, on 1 February 2012, by rule 4 of the High Court Amendment Rules (No 2) 2011 (SR 2011/351).

prov.heading: Public interest

para.text: The rules that relate to interrogatories do not affect any rule of law that authorises or requires the withholding of a matter on the ground that its disclosure would be injurious to the public interest.

prov.cf: 1908 No 89 Schedule 2 r 8.12 prior to 1 February 2012

history.history-note: Schedule 2 rule 8.45: inserted, on 1 February 2012, by rule 4 of the High Court Amendment Rules (No 2) 2011 (SR 2011/351).

prov.heading: Defamation proceedings

para.text: If, in a proceeding for defamation, the defendant pleads that the words or matters complained of are honest opinion on a matter of public interest or were published on a privileged occasion, no interrogatories as to the defendant's sources of information or grounds of belief may be allowed unless the interrogatories are necessary in the interests of justice.

prov.cf: 1908 No 89 Schedule 2 r 8.13 prior to 1 February 2012

history.history-note: Schedule 2 rule 8.46: inserted, on 1 February 2012, by rule 4 of the High Court Amendment Rules (No 2) 2011 (SR 2011/351).
Schedule 2 Part 8 subpart 3: replaced, on 1 February 2012, by rule 4 of the High Court Amendment Rules (No 2) 2011 (SR 2011/351).

prov.heading: Notice to admit facts

para.text: A party who is entitled to serve a notice under rule 8.34 may at any time serve on another party a notice requiring the party to admit, for the purpose of the proceeding only, the facts specified in the notice.
The notice must be in form G 36.
An admission made in compliance with a notice under subclause (1)—
may be amended or withdrawn by the party by whom it was made at any time if a Judge so allows, and this may be done on any terms the Judge thinks just:
must not be used against the party by whom it was made in a proceeding or interlocutory application other than the proceeding or interlocutory application for which it was made.

If the party on whom a notice to admit facts has been served under subclause (1) refuses or neglects to admit the facts within 5 working days after the day of service or within any longer time allowed by a Judge, the costs of proving the facts must be paid by that party, unless a Judge otherwise orders.

prov.cf: 1908 No 89 Schedule 2 r 8.14 prior to 1 February 2012

history.history-note: Schedule 2 rule 8.47: inserted, on 1 February 2012, by rule 4 of the High Court Amendment Rules (No 2) 2011 (SR 2011/351).

prov.heading: Judgment on admission of facts

para.text: A judgment or order may be made on an admission of facts under rule 15.15.

prov.cf: 1908 No 89 Schedule 2 r 8.15 prior to 1 February 2012

history.history-note: Schedule 2 rule 8.48: inserted, on 1 February 2012, by rule 4 of the High Court Amendment Rules (No 2) 2011 (SR 2011/351).

subpart.heading: Briefs, oral evidence directions, common bundles, and chronologies

history.history-note: Schedule 2 Part 9 subpart 1: replaced, on 4 February 2013, by rule 20 of the High Court Amendment Rules (No 2) 2012 (SR 2012/409).

para.text: When applying the rules in this subpart to a proceeding, the court and the parties must pursue the just, speedy, and inexpensive determination of that proceeding.
The parties must also ensure that the briefs and the common bundle are commensurate with the goal of keeping the cost of the proceeding proportionate to the subject matter of the proceeding.
The documents to be produced at the trial or hearing and the evidence-in-chief of witnesses must be prepared, produced, and led in accordance with this subpart.

history.history-note: Schedule 2 rule 9.1: replaced, on 4 February 2013, by rule 20 of the High Court Amendment Rules (No 2) 2012 (SR 2012/409).

para.text: In this rule, documents to be relied upon means—
documents referred to in a brief or to be referred to by a witness; and
documents intended to be put to witnesses called by another party; and
documents to be referred to in opening.

When a party discloses documents to be relied upon at the trial or hearing, that party must supply a list of those documents incorporating any list previously supplied, so that the other parties always have an up-to-date list of the documents that party intends to rely upon. The list may be in any format and is to be labelled and referred to as that party's index.

Documents to be relied upon at the trial or hearing but additional to those already disclosed may be disclosed at any time, but not later than a date fixed by the court at a case management, issues, or pre-trial conference.
Subclause (3) does not affect a party's ongoing obligations in relation to discovery.

history.history-note: Schedule 2 rule 9.2: replaced, on 4 February 2013, by rule 20 of the High Court Amendment Rules (No 2) 2012 (SR 2012/409).

para.text: Unless otherwise ordered by the court, a common bundle of documents must not be prepared until all the briefs of the parties have been served.

The common bundle must be prepared by the plaintiff (or a different party, if the court so orders) and filed and served by a date fixed by the court at a case management, issues, or pre-trial conference.

history.history-note: Schedule 2 rule 9.3: replaced, on 4 February 2013, by rule 20 of the High Court Amendment Rules (No 2) 2012 (SR 2012/409).

prov.heading: Preparation of common bundle

para.text: The parties must co-operate in the preparation of a bundle of documents (in this subpart referred to as the common bundle).
The duty to co-operate includes—

advising the plaintiff or the plaintiff's counsel promptly, after the date when the last brief of any party is served under rule 9.7, of the documents that the party requires the plaintiff to include in the common bundle; and

taking all practicable steps to assist the plaintiff in the preparation of the common bundle, for example, by making copies of documents available, or agreeing to the excision of part of a document if that part cannot be relevant; and
conferring as to the format of the common bundle and, in particular, whether an electronic format of the common bundle is appropriate.
If a party other than the plaintiff has been ordered to prepare the common bundle, the references in subclause (2) to the plaintiff are to be read as references to that different party.
Subject to rule 9.6, the common bundle must contain all the documents listed in the index of each party, and no other documents.
The common bundle must—
arrange the documents chronologically, or in any other appropriate sequence or manner agreed by counsel and approved by the court:
number each page of the common bundle in a consecutive sequence:
set out before the first document a common bundle index that shows—
a short description of each document:
the date of each document:
the party from whose custody each document has been produced:
the page number of each document as it appears in the common bundle:
use a format that is, so far as possible, compatible with that used by the parties when listing documents under rule 8.16 (schedule appended to affidavit of documents).

If the parties have agreed to use an electronic format for the common bundle, the parties must have regard to any practice note on electronic formats issued from time to time by the Chief High Court Judge.
Unless the court directs otherwise, the common bundle must be served not later than 15 working days after the date when the last brief of any party is served under rule 9.7.

prov.cf: 1908 No 89 Schedule 2 r 9.13 prior to 1 February 2013

history.history-note: Schedule 2 rule 9.4: replaced, on 4 February 2013, by rule 20 of the High Court Amendment Rules (No 2) 2012 (SR 2012/409).
Schedule 2 rule 9.4(2)﻿(c): amended, on 11 November 2013, by rule 16(1) of the High Court Amendment Rules (No 3) 2013 (SR 2013/425).
Schedule 2 rule 9.4(5A): inserted, on 11 November 2013, by rule 16(2) of the High Court Amendment Rules (No 3) 2013 (SR 2013/425).

prov.heading: Consequences of incorporating document in common bundle

para.text: Each document contained in the common bundle is, unless the court otherwise directs, to be considered—
to be admissible; and
to be accurately described in the common bundle index; and
to be what it appears to be; and
to have been signed by any apparent signatory; and
to have been sent by any apparent author and to have been received by any apparent addressee; and
to have been produced by the party indicated in the common bundle index.

If a party objects to the admissibility of a document included in the common bundle, or to the application of any of subclause (1)﻿(b) to (f) to a document, the objection must, if practicable, be recorded in the common bundle, and must be determined by the court at the hearing or at any prior time that the court directs.
The fact that a document has been included in the common bundle is not relevant to the determination under subclause (2) of an objection that relates to the document.

A document in the common bundle is automatically received into evidence (subject to the resolution of any objection to admissibility) when a witness refers to it in evidence or when counsel refers to it in submissions (made otherwise than in a closing address).
A document in the common bundle may not be received in evidence except under subclause (4).
The court may direct that this rule or any part of it is not to apply to a particular document.

prov.cf: 1908 No 89 Schedule 2 r 9.14 prior to 1 February 2013

history.history-note: Schedule 2 rule 9.5: replaced, on 4 February 2013, by rule 20 of the High Court Amendment Rules (No 2) 2012 (SR 2012/409).

prov.heading: Consequence of not incorporating document in common bundle

para.text: A document not incorporated in the common bundle may be produced at the trial or hearing only with the leave of the court.
The court may grant leave to produce a discovered document not so incorporated unless its production would cause an injustice.
The court may refuse leave to produce a document not so incorporated and not discovered if its production might cause an injustice.

prov.cf: 1908 No 89 Schedule 2 r 9.15 prior to 1 February 2013

history.history-note: Schedule 2 rule 9.6: replaced, on 4 February 2013, by rule 20 of the High Court Amendment Rules (No 2) 2012 (SR 2012/409).

prov.heading: Requirements in relation to briefs

para.text: In this subpart, brief, in relation to the evidence of a witness to be called by a party, means a written statement setting out evidence proposed to be given by that witness.

The date by which the parties must complete and serve briefs upon each other, simultaneously or sequentially, must be determined by the court at a case management or issues conference, having regard to the needs of the case.
Whether or not some evidence is directed to be led orally, the brief must contain the testimony intended to be taken from that witness on that subject.
Every brief—
must be signed by the witness by whom the brief is made:
must be in the words of the witness and not in the words of the lawyer involved in drafting the brief:
must not contain evidence that is inadmissible in the proceeding:
must not contain any material in the nature of a submission:
must avoid repetition:
must avoid the recital of the contents or a summary of documents that are to be produced in any event:
must be confined to the matters in issue.

If the brief does not comply with the requirements of subclause (4) the court, prior to or during the trial, may direct that it not be read in whole or in part, and may make such order as to costs as the court sees fit.
When a brief is served, the party serving it must as soon as practicable advise the Registrar what has been served, upon whom, and the date of service.

prov.cf: 1908 No 89 Schedule 2 r 9.4 prior to 1 February 2013

history.history-note: Schedule 2 rule 9.7: replaced, on 4 February 2013, by rule 20 of the High Court Amendment Rules (No 2) 2012 (SR 2012/409).

prov.heading: Supplementary briefs

para.text: A party wishing to offer a supplementary brief must serve it as soon as possible.
The acceptance and use of the supplementary brief in court will be at the discretion of the trial Judge.

prov.cf: 1908 No 89 Schedule 2 r 9.5 prior to 1 February 2013

history.history-note: Schedule 2 rule 9.8: replaced, on 4 February 2013, by rule 20 of the High Court Amendment Rules (No 2) 2012 (SR 2012/409).

prov.heading: Exchange of chronology of facts intended to be relied upon at trial or hearing

para.text: The plaintiff must, not later than 15 working days after the common bundle has been served, file and serve a chronology of the facts it intends to rely upon at the trial or hearing.
In preparing the chronology, the plaintiff must—
set out the facts in chronological order; and
cross-reference the facts to—
1 or more documents; or
1 or more statements in written briefs; and
include, when available, common bundle index references or page references.

The other parties must, not later than 15 working days after service of the plaintiff's chronology, file and serve their responses to it, identifying which facts they dispute, and adding any other facts they intend to rely upon.
In preparing their responses, the other parties must—
cross-reference disputed facts to different or contradictory facts in the plaintiff's chronology; and
list any additional facts; and
comply with subclause (2)﻿(b).
The court may modify the requirements of this rule at a conference under rule 7.5.

history.history-note: Schedule 2 rule 9.9: replaced, on 4 February 2013, by rule 20 of the High Court Amendment Rules (No 2) 2012 (SR 2012/409).

para.text: After the preparation and service of the chronologies of facts, the parties must bring significant facts that are disputed to the attention of the court.

The obligation in subclause (1) may be discharged at a case management or issues or pre-trial conference, or at another time, but must, in any event, be discharged not later than 15 working days after service of the chronologies of fact has been completed.
The court may, before the giving of evidence, and either before or at the trial or hearing, direct that evidence be given orally (an oral evidence direction).

history.history-note: Schedule 2 rule 9.10: replaced, on 4 February 2013, by rule 20 of the High Court Amendment Rules (No 2) 2012 (SR 2012/409).

para.text: Any challenge to the admissibility of a brief, in whole or in part, must be notified to the party or parties concerned within 20 working days after receipt of the brief by the challenging party.
If the issue is not resolved between counsel in a further 10 working days, notice that there is an admissibility issue must be given to the court by the challenging party.

history.history-note: Schedule 2 rule 9.11: replaced, on 4 February 2013, by rule 20 of the High Court Amendment Rules (No 2) 2012 (SR 2012/409).

prov.heading: Evidence-in-chief at trial

para.text: A brief signed by a witness—
must, subject to the terms of an oral evidence direction made under rule 9.10, be read by the witness at the trial as the witness's evidence-in-chief; and
is, when read by the witness at the trial, the evidence-in-chief given by the witness at the trial; and
must, after being read by the witness at the trial, be endorsed by or on behalf of the Registrar with the words Given in evidence on [date].
Any portion of the brief that is the subject of an oral evidence direction under rule 9.10 becomes part of the evidence-in-chief of the witness only if and when it is given orally.

prov.cf: 1908 No 89 Schedule 2 r 9.6 prior to 1 February 2013

history.history-note: Schedule 2 rule 9.12: replaced, on 4 February 2013, by rule 20 of the High Court Amendment Rules (No 2) 2012 (SR 2012/409).

prov.heading: Briefs not given in evidence

para.text: If, by the time that a party opens the party's case, the brief of another party's witness has not been given in evidence, the party may, in opening, refer to that brief only with the leave of the trial Judge.

When any part of the evidence contained in a brief is not given in evidence at the trial by the person who signed the brief, any other party to the proceeding may, unless the trial Judge otherwise directs, put that part of the evidence to that person in cross-examination.

prov.cf: 1908 No 89 Schedule 2 rr 9.8, 9.9 prior to 1 February 2013

history.history-note: Schedule 2 rule 9.13: replaced, on 4 February 2013, by rule 20 of the High Court Amendment Rules (No 2) 2012 (SR 2012/409).

prov.heading: Privilege and admissibility not affected by briefs

para.text: Nothing in this subpart—
deprives any party of that party's right to treat any communication as privileged; or
changes inadmissible evidence into admissible evidence; or
changes admissible evidence into inadmissible evidence; or
deprives any party of that party's right to cross-examine any party to a proceeding on a brief, served under these rules, that is inconsistent with a statement previously made by that party; or
allows a brief, served under these rules, to be made available, before it is given in evidence, for use for another purpose or proceeding.

prov.cf: 1908 No 89 Schedule 2 r 9.10 prior to 1 February 2013

history.history-note: Schedule 2 rule 9.14: replaced, on 4 February 2013, by rule 20 of the High Court Amendment Rules (No 2) 2012 (SR 2012/409).

prov.heading: Cross-examination duties

para.text: The exchange of briefs under this subpart does not affect the cross-examination duties referred to in section 92 of the Evidence Act 2006.

prov.cf: 1908 No 89 Schedule 2 r 9.11 prior to 1 February 2013

history.history-note: Schedule 2 rule 9.15: replaced, on 4 February 2013, by rule 20 of the High Court Amendment Rules (No 2) 2012 (SR 2012/409).

para.text: The plaintiff must, not later than 2 working days before the trial or hearing, file in the court and serve on every other party to the proceeding a copy of the plaintiff's opening.

history.history-note: Schedule 2 rule 9.16: replaced, on 4 February 2013, by rule 20 of the High Court Amendment Rules (No 2) 2012 (SR 2012/409).

prov.heading: Order for examination of witness or for letters of request

para.text: When, in a proceeding or on an interlocutory application, a party desires to have the evidence of a person or persons taken otherwise than at the trial or the hearing of that interlocutory application, the court may, on application by that party, make orders on any terms the court thinks just—

for the examination of a person on oath before a Judge, Registrar, or Deputy Registrar or before a person that the court appoints (in rules 9.18 to 9.23 referred to as the examiner) at any place whether in or out of New Zealand; or
for the sending of a letter of request to the judicial authorities of another country, to take, or cause to be taken, the evidence of a person.

On the application of an opposite party, the court may, if it is satisfied that the party who obtained the order under subclause (1) is not implementing the order with due diligence, rescind the order and may make any other order justice requires.

prov.heading: Security for costs for taking evidence outside New Zealand

para.text: The court may, as a condition of making an order under rule 9.17 for the taking of evidence outside New Zealand, require the party applying to give security for—
the estimated fees and expenses of the examiner, or other person by or before whom the evidence is to be taken; and

the costs of any opposite party of and incidental to the taking of the evidence, for the amount the court thinks just, but not exceeding the estimated reasonable indemnity costs and disbursements of that opposite party.

The party obtaining an order for examination before an examiner must, unless the examination is conducted by the Registrar or Deputy Registrar at the court where the file of the proceeding is held, furnish the examiner with copies of those documents in the proceeding that are necessary to inform the examiner of the matters to which the examination is to relate.

If the documents in the proceeding are not sufficient to inform the examiner of the matters to which the examination is to relate, the court must, in the order for examination or in a later order, state those matters.
On receipt of a copy of the order for examination, the examiner must appoint a time and place for the examination and notify all parties of the time and place.
The examiner may adjourn the examination from time to time and from place to place as is necessary or expedient.
The examiner may administer an oath to each witness examined and each witness may be examined, cross-examined, and re-examined as at the trial of a proceeding.
The examiner must ensure that evidence given at the examination is recorded, together with notes of any objections to the evidence.
The depositions so taken must be signed on each page by the witness and by the examiner.

The depositions when taken must be securely fastened together and must, together with the exhibits and the report of the examiner, be sent without delay to the registry of the court in which the file of the proceeding is for the time being held.
The examiner may send to the registry of the court in which the file of the proceeding is for the time being held a certificate stating that—
at the time and place appointed for the examination or at any adjournment, there was no appearance by or on behalf of the party obtaining the order; or
the witness did not attend at that time and place; or
at that time and place, the applicant intimated that it was not intended to proceed with the taking of the evidence.
On application to the Registrar a party may inspect any depositions taken under this rule and make copies of them or extracts from them.
The examiner may, with the consent in writing of all parties to the proceeding, take the examination of a person in addition to the person named or referred to in the order for examination.
The consent of each of the parties must be attached to the deposition of that person.
When objection is taken to a question to a person being examined before an examiner, or a witness takes objection to answering a question or to producing a document or a thing,—
the examiner must give the parties the examiner’s opinion on the objection, but must not rule on it; and

the question, the ground for the objection, the opinion of the examiner, and the answer (if any) to the question must be set out in the deposition of the witness or in a statement attached to the deposition; and
the court may, on application by a party, decide the validity of the objection.
The report of the examiner may be in form G 19.

Depositions taken in accordance with these rules under an order under rule 9.17 may be produced as evidence at the trial of the proceeding and must be received subject to any objection on the ground of admissibility.

prov.heading: Letters of request where convention exists

para.text: When a convention is in force between a country and New Zealand relating to the taking of evidence in that country for use in New Zealand, rules 9.26 to 9.28 apply subject to any special provisions contained in the convention.
When an order has been made for the issue of a letter of request, the party obtaining the order must—
lodge with the Registrar—
a form of the appropriate letter of request; and
the interrogatories and cross-interrogatories (if any) to accompany the letter of request; and
where required by the convention, a translation of each of the documents mentioned in subparagraphs (i) and (ii) into the language, or an appropriate language, of the country concerned; and
file—
a copy of each of the documents mentioned in paragraph (a); and

a personal undertaking by the party obtaining the order or the party’s solicitor to be responsible for all expenses in respect of the execution of the letter of request incurred by the court or by any person at the request of the court, and, on being given notice of the amount of those expenses, to pay the amount forthwith into a Crown Bank Account and produce evidence of the payment to the Registrar.
The correctness of every translation must be certified or otherwise verified to the satisfaction of the Registrar.
The Registrar may require security of a reasonable amount instead of an undertaking under subclause (1)﻿(b)﻿(ii).
The letter of request must be in such form as the court approves and be issued under the hand of a Judge and the seal of the court.

The party who obtains an order for the issue of a letter of request must file a statement of the names and addresses of the parties’ agents in the country in which the letter of request is to be executed.

prov.heading: Consequences of non-compliance with undertaking as to expenses

para.text: When a party who has given an undertaking under rule 9.26(1)﻿(b)﻿(ii) does not, within 5 working days after being served with notice of the amount of the expenses concerned, pay that amount to the Registrar, the court may, on application by the Registrar,—
order the party to pay the amount of the expenses to the Registrar; and
until payment, stay the proceeding as far as concerns the whole or any part of any claim for relief by that party; and
strike out any pleading filed by that party.

prov.heading: Application by Solicitor-General on letters of request from abroad

para.text: The Registrar must transmit to the Solicitor-General a letter of request received if—
the letter relates to a proceeding to which sections 184 and 185 of the Evidence Act 2006 apply; and
it appears that the letter is not to be given effect by an application by a party to the proceeding.
The Solicitor-General may then make an application and take any steps that are necessary to give effect to the letter.
An order under section 100(1) of the Act may be made—
at any time after the time for filing a statement of defence to the plaintiff’s statement of claim has expired, on the application of any party to the proceeding; or
by the court on its own initiative.
The time and place of the examination must be fixed by the order.
When an order is made under section 100(1) of the Act the court may require a medical practitioner making the examination—
to furnish to the court, within the time specified in the order, a report in writing setting out—
the medical practitioner’s clinical findings; and
the medical practitioner’s opinion of the physical condition or mental condition or both of the person examined, so far as relevant; and
if appropriate, the medical practitioner’s prognosis in respect of the condition; and
to deliver, within the same time, a copy of the report to the party (if any) who applied for the order.

Unless the court otherwise directs, the party to whom the copy of the report is delivered under rule 9.31(b) must immediately serve a copy of the report on the person examined or that person’s solicitor and the other parties.

If the order under section 100(1) of the Act was made by the court on its own initiative, the Registrar must, as soon as practicable after the report is furnished to the court, serve a copy of the report on the parties to the proceeding.

prov.heading: Evidence of medical practitioner when medical examination ordered

para.text: If the parties do not agree to accept a report obtained under an order under section 100(1) of the Act, the court—
may summon the medical practitioner named in the order to attend at the trial; and
may, at any appropriate stage of the trial before counsels' addresses, examine the medical practitioner on the report; and
may permit any party to cross-examine the medical practitioner on the evidence then given.
The court may, for the purpose of enabling the proper determination of any matter in question in a proceeding, make orders, on terms, for—
the inspection of any property:
the taking of samples of any property:
the observation of any property:
the measuring, weighing, or photographing of any property:
the conduct of an experiment on or with any property:
the observation of a process.
An order may authorise a person to enter any land or do anything else for the purpose of getting access to the property.
In this rule, property includes any land and any document or other chattel, whether in the control of a party or not.
A party applying for an order under rule 9.34 must, so far as practicable, serve notice of the application on each person who would be affected by the order if made.

In a proceeding that is to be tried by Judge alone and in which a question for an expert witness arises, the court may at any time, on its own initiative or on the application of a party, appoint an independent expert, or, if more than 1 such question arises, 2 or more such experts, to inquire into and report upon any question of fact or opinion not involving questions of law or of construction.
An expert appointed under subclause (1) is referred to in this rule and in rules 9.37 to 9.42 as a court expert.
A court expert in a proceeding must, if possible, be a person agreed upon by the parties and, failing agreement, the court must appoint the court expert from persons named by the parties.
A person appointed as an independent expert in a proceeding under rule 9.44(3) may not be appointed as a court expert unless the parties agree.

In this rule, expert, in relation to a question arising in a proceeding, means a person who has the knowledge or experience of, or in connection with, that question that makes that person’s opinion on it admissible in evidence.

prov.heading: Submission of question to court expert

para.text: The question to be submitted to the court expert and the instructions (if any) given to the court expert must, failing agreement between the parties, be settled by the court.
The court expert must send his or her report to the court, together with whatever number of copies the court directs.
The Registrar must send copies of the report to the parties or their solicitors.
The court may direct the court expert to make a further or supplemental report.
Any part of the court expert’s report not accepted by all the parties must be treated as information furnished to the court and given appropriate weight.
If the court expert is of the opinion that an experiment or test of any kind (other than one of a trifling character) is necessary for the making of a satisfactory report, the court expert—
must inform the parties or their solicitors; and
must, if possible, make an arrangement with the parties or their solicitors about—
the expenses involved; and
the persons to attend the experiment or test; and
any other relevant matters.
The court must settle any matters on which the parties or their solicitors are unable to agree.
Any party may, within 10 working days after receiving a copy of the court expert’s report, apply to the court for an order under subclause (2).
On an application under subclause (1), the court must make an order for the cross-examination of the court expert by all parties, either—
at the trial; or
before an examiner at such time and place as may be specified in the order.
The remuneration of the court expert must be fixed by the court and include—
a fee for the report; and
a proper sum for each day during which he or she is required to be present either in court or before an examiner.

The court may, by the order appointing the court expert or subsequently, make any order it thinks just for and incidental to the payment of the remuneration of the court expert including either or both of the following:
an order directing that the remuneration of the court expert must be paid by 1 or more of the parties and, if more than 1, in the proportions the court thinks just:
an order that any party or parties give security, on any terms the court thinks just, for the remuneration of the court expert.

When the court appoints the court expert on its own initiative, the court, instead of making an order under subclause (2), may, by the order appointing the expert or subsequently, order that the remuneration of the court expert must be paid by the chief executive of the Ministry of Justice out of money appropriated by Parliament for the purpose.
Subclauses (2) and (3) do not affect the power of the court to make an order providing for the payment of the court expert’s remuneration as part of the costs of the proceeding.

If a court expert is appointed in a proceeding or an interlocutory application, a party may call 1 expert witness, or with leave, more than 1, to give evidence on the question reported on by the court expert, if the party gives notice of the intention to do so a reasonable time before the trial.
The court must not grant leave under subclause (1) unless the circumstances are exceptional.

prov.heading: Expert witness to comply with code of conduct

para.text: A party to a proceeding who engages an expert witness must give the expert witness a copy of the code of conduct set out in Schedule 4.
An expert witness must—

state in any written statement of the proposed evidence of the witness served under rule 9.2 or 9.3, or at the time of giving any oral evidence, or in any affidavit containing the evidence of the expert witness, that the expert witness has read the code of conduct and agrees to comply with it:

comply with the code of conduct in preparing any written statement of the proposed evidence of the witness to be served under rule 9.2 or 9.3 or in giving any oral or affidavit evidence in any proceeding.
The evidence of an expert witness who has not complied with subclause (2)﻿(a) may be offered only with the leave of the court.

prov.heading: Court may direct conference of expert witnesses

para.text: The court may, on its own initiative or on the application of a party to a proceeding, direct expert witnesses to—
confer on specified matters:
confer in the absence of the legal advisers of the parties:
try to reach agreement on matters in issue in the proceeding:
prepare and sign a joint witness statement stating the matters on which the expert witnesses agree and the matters on which they do not agree, including the reasons for their disagreement:
prepare the joint witness statement without the assistance of the legal advisers of the parties.
The court must not give a direction under subclause (1)﻿(b) or (e) unless the parties agree.
The court may, on its own initiative or on the application of a party to the proceeding,—
appoint an independent expert to convene and conduct the conference of expert witnesses:
give any directions for convening and conducting the conference the court thinks just.
The court may not appoint an independent expert or give a direction under subclause (3) unless the parties agree.
Subject to any subsequent order of the court as to costs, the court may determine the remuneration of an independent expert and the party by whom it must be paid.
The matters discussed at the conference of the expert witnesses must not be referred to at the hearing unless the parties by whom the expert witnesses have been engaged agree.
An independent expert appointed under subclause (3) may not give evidence at the hearing unless the parties agree.

prov.heading: Status of joint witness statement by expert witnesses

para.text: A joint witness statement prepared by expert witnesses under rule 9.44—
must be circulated by the parties to the proceeding by whom the expert witnesses have been engaged to every other party who has given an address for service; and
may be produced in evidence by any expert witness who signed the statement; and
may, if the parties to the proceeding agree, be produced in evidence without the need to call any of the expert witnesses who signed the statement.
Rules 9.4 to 9.11 apply, with all necessary modifications, to a joint witness statement as if the statement were a written statement under rule 9.2 or 9.3.

An expert witness is not precluded from giving evidence on any matter at the hearing simply because the expert witness has participated in the preparation of a joint witness statement under rule 9.44 or because the witness statement is evidence at the hearing under rule 9.6.

prov.heading: Evidence of expert witnesses at trial

para.text: The court may, at the hearing, direct that the evidence of expert witnesses is given after all or certain factual evidence is given or in a sequence the court thinks best suited to the circumstances of the proceeding.
A person may apply by originating application for an order for the examination of a witness whose evidence may be material for establishing a right or claim—
to any estate or interest in property, or to any other relief, to which the person would, in the circumstances alleged to exist, become entitled, on the happening of a future event; and
that cannot be established before the happening of the future event.

prov.heading: Procedures in which the Crown may have interest

para.text: If the Crown may have an estate or interest in the property or in the right or claim, the applicant may join the Crown as a respondent.

An application under rule 9.47 is not to be set down for hearing but the court may make an appropriate order under rules 9.17 to 9.19 for the examination of a witness (whether offered by the applicant or another party).

Evidence taken under rule 9.49 may subsequently be offered at the trial of a proceeding to enforce the claim or interest to which it relates and is admissible unless it is inadmissible in whole or in part under the Evidence Act 2006.

Unless otherwise directed by the court or required or authorised by these rules or by an Act, disputed questions of fact arising at the trial of any proceeding must be determined on evidence given by means of witnesses examined orally in open court.

Orders of subpoena in form G 25 to require the attendance of witnesses at the trial to testify or to produce documents, or both, may be obtained by any party, at any time after the filing of the statement of claim.
A party requiring the issue of an order of subpoena must file a written request to obtain it.
The names of more than 1 witness may be included in an order of subpoena, but it is not necessary to show the names on the written request.
Upon receiving a written request under this rule the Registrar must forthwith issue the order or orders of subpoena requested.

history.history-note: Schedule 2 rule 9.52(4): inserted, on 1 December 2009, by rule 6 of the High Court Amendment Rules (No 2) 2009 (SR 2009/334).

para.text: The order of subpoena must be served on the witness personally, by leaving a sealed copy of it with the witness, together with any allowances and travelling expenses required by section 56A(3) of the Act.
An application for an order under section 65 of the Corrections Act 2004 may be made without notice.
In a proceeding heard by a Judge alone, the parties may file an agreement signed by the parties, that the evidence, or any part of the evidence, is to be given by affidavit.
Despite an agreement filed under subclause (1), the court may direct that evidence of any disputed fact or issue be given in accordance with rule 9.51.

prov.heading: Affidavit evidence under order of court

para.text: The court may, even though no agreement for the giving of evidence by affidavit has been made, at any time for sufficient reason order, on reasonable conditions,—
that any particular fact or facts may be proved by affidavit; or
that the evidence of any witness may be given by affidavit read at the trial or on any application for judgment.
Despite subclause (1), an order must not be made authorising the evidence of the witness to be given by affidavit if—
an opposite party desires the production of a witness for cross-examination; and
the witness can be produced.
Subclause (2) is subject to any order made under rule 7.2 or 7.8, as the case requires.

history.history-note: Schedule 2 rule 9.56(3): amended, on 11 November 2013, by rule 17 of the High Court Amendment Rules (No 3) 2013 (SR 2013/425).

para.text: If the parties so agree, the evidence at the trial of any proceeding heard by a Judge alone, or any issue in that proceeding, may be given, without examining any witnesses or filing any affidavits, by a statement of facts agreed upon by the parties.
Despite the agreement, the court may direct that evidence of any fact or matter be given in accordance with rule 9.51 or 9.56.
Every agreement under subclause (1) must be in writing signed by the parties and must be filed.
The agreement must set out the facts agreed upon and the court is entitled to draw any necessary inferences from the agreed facts.
In rules 9.59 to 9.67, unless the context otherwise requires, terms that are defined in the Evidence Act 2006 have the meanings given to them by that Act.

prov.heading: Issue of subpoenas by High Court for service in Australia

para.text: An order of subpoena of the High Court for service on a witness in Australia that requires the witness to testify, whether or not it also requires the witness to produce documents or things, must be in form G 26.

An order of subpoena of the High Court for service on a witness in Australia that requires the witness to produce documents or things, but does not require the witness to testify, must be in form G 27.
An order of subpoena referred to in subclause (1) or (2) may be obtained in the same manner and subject to the same conditions as an order of subpoena under rule 9.52.

prov.heading: Leave to serve New Zealand subpoena on witness in Australia

para.text: An application for leave to serve a New Zealand subpoena on a witness in Australia must be made without notice by originating application and Part 19 applies, with all necessary modifications, to the application.
Every application for leave to serve a New Zealand subpoena on a witness in Australia must be accompanied by an affidavit containing the following matters:
the name, occupation, and residential address of the witness:
proof that the witness has attained the age of 18 years:

if the subpoena requires the witness to testify and to attend at the New Zealand court, whether consideration has been given to requiring the witness to testify from Australia by remote appearance medium and the reason it is not considered appropriate that the witness do so:
the latest date proposed for service of the subpoena:
if the subpoena requires the witness to attend at the New Zealand court or at any other place,—
the availability of suitable means of transport to enable the witness to comply with the subpoena:
an estimate of the length of time that the witness will be required to attend at the court or other place:
an estimate of the cost of transport and accommodation likely to be incurred by the witness in complying with the subpoena:
the amounts or the amounts represented by vouchers, as the case may be, proposed to be paid or tendered to the witness to enable the witness to comply with the subpoena:
if the applicant is aware of any fact or circumstance that may constitute a ground for setting the subpoena aside under section 160 of the Evidence Act 2006, the fact or circumstance.

A Judge may direct that a New Zealand subpoena be served in Australia on a body corporate by serving the subpoena on a member, officer, or employee of the body corporate in the manner the Judge directs.
The file relating to an application must be kept separate from the file relating to the proceeding to which the subpoena relates.
As provided in rule 3.12(4), no document relating to an application under this rule may be searched, inspected, or copied without the leave of a Judge.

history.history-note: Schedule 2 rule 9.60(2)﻿(c): amended, on 11 October 2013, by rule 17 of the High Court (Trans-Tasman Proceedings Act 2010) Amendment Rules 2013 (SR 2013/351).
Schedule 2 rule 9.60(5): amended, on 3 June 2014, by rule 4 of the High Court Amendment Rules 2014 (LI 2014/127).
Schedule 2 rule 9.60(5): amended, on 12 June 2009, by rule 5 of the High Court (Access to Court Documents) Amendment Rules 2009 (SR 2009/133).

prov.heading: Service of subpoena on witness in Australia

para.text: Every statement that, in accordance with section 156 of the Evidence Act 2006, is required to accompany a subpoena that is served on a witness in Australia must be in form G 28.

prov.heading: Application to set aside New Zealand subpoena

para.text: An application to set aside a New Zealand subpoena served on a witness in Australia may be filed by—
a person who is entitled to file documents under these rules; or
a person who is entitled to practise as a solicitor of a Supreme Court of a State or Territory of Australia.
The application—
may state (for the purposes of rule 9.64(1)) that a hearing is required to determine the application; and
may be filed by sending it by fax or email to the registry of the relevant court in which leave to serve the subpoena was given.
Every application must be made by way of interlocutory application.
The heading on the application may be the same as the heading on the order granting leave to serve the subpoena.
Every application—
must state an address in New Zealand or Australia that is the applicant’s address for service:
may state a fax number in New Zealand or Australia to which documents relating to the application may be sent to the applicant.
If the application is filed by fax or email, the Registrar—
must send by fax or email to the applicant or the applicant’s solicitor, as the case may be, an acknowledgement that the application has been received:
may, if the application is not clear or legible, require the applicant or the applicant’s solicitor, as the case may be, to transmit the application by fax or email again.

history.history-note: Schedule 2 rule 9.62(1)﻿(b): amended, on 11 October 2013, by rule 18(1) of the High Court (Trans-Tasman Proceedings Act 2010) Amendment Rules 2013 (SR 2013/351).
Schedule 2 rule 9.62(2): replaced, on 11 October 2013, by rule 18(2) of the High Court (Trans-Tasman Proceedings Act 2010) Amendment Rules 2013 (SR 2013/351).
Schedule 2 rule 9.62(6): replaced, on 11 October 2013, by rule 18(3) of the High Court (Trans-Tasman Proceedings Act 2010) Amendment Rules 2013 (SR 2013/351).

para.text: A document relating to an application to set aside a New Zealand subpoena may be served on the applicant by—
leaving it at, or posting it to, the address for service of the applicant stated in the application; or
if a fax number is stated in the application, sending it by fax to that number.
If a document relating to the application is served on the applicant by post in accordance with subclause (1)﻿(a), it is to be treated as having been served on the earlier of—
the eighth working day after the day on which it was posted; and
the day on which it was received.
If a document relating to the application is served on the applicant by fax, the document must, subject to subclauses (3) and (4), be treated as having been served on the day on which it was sent.

If a document is sent by fax to a fax number in a State or Territory of Australia at a time later than 5 pm in that State or Territory, the document must, subject to subclause (4), be treated as having been served on the first working day after the day on which it was sent.
A document sent to a fax number in Australia must, unless the contrary is proved, be treated as having been received in a complete and legible condition.

history.history-note: Schedule 2 rule 9.63(1)﻿(a): amended, on 11 October 2013, by rule 19(1) of the High Court (Trans-Tasman Proceedings Act 2010) Amendment Rules 2013 (SR 2013/351).
Schedule 2 rule 9.63(1A): inserted, on 11 October 2013, by rule 19(2) of the High Court (Trans-Tasman Proceedings Act 2010) Amendment Rules 2013 (SR 2013/351).
Schedule 2 rule 9.63(1A)﻿(a): amended, on 1 July 2015, by rule 8 of the High Court Amendment Rules 2015 (LI 2015/102).

para.text: Despite any other rule, if neither the applicant for an order to set aside a New Zealand subpoena nor the person at whose request the subpoena was issued states that a hearing is required, the court may determine an application to set the subpoena aside without a hearing.
For the purposes of determining an application, the court may, if it thinks fit, hold a hearing by remote appearance medium under section 168 of the Evidence Act 2006.

Subject to the Evidence Act 2006, the court must hold a hearing by remote appearance medium if the applicant requests, either in the application or within a reasonable time after the filing of the application, that a hearing be held by remote appearance medium.

history.history-note: Schedule 2 rule 9.64(2): amended, on 11 October 2013, by rule 20 of the High Court (Trans-Tasman Proceedings Act 2010) Amendment Rules 2013 (SR 2013/351).
Schedule 2 rule 9.64(3): amended, on 11 October 2013, by rule 20 of the High Court (Trans-Tasman Proceedings Act 2010) Amendment Rules 2013 (SR 2013/351).

para.text: A certificate under section 161 of the Evidence Act 2006 must be in form G 29.

prov.heading: Transmission of documents or things to Australian Court

para.text: Every person who produces a document or thing at a registry of the court in compliance with an Australian subpoena must provide the Registrar with a copy of the subpoena.
When a document or thing is produced at a registry of the court, the Registrar must, on compliance with subclause (1),—
issue a receipt for the document or thing that states the date and time of its production; and
send to the Registrar of the Australian Court that issued the subpoena, by fax or other means of communication, a copy of the receipt and of the subpoena; and

send the document or thing together with a copy of the subpoena, without delay, to the Australian Court by means enabling it to be received before the date on which it is required to be produced to that court.

prov.heading: Evidence and submissions by remote appearance medium from Australia

para.text: An application under section 168 of the Evidence Act 2006 for a direction that evidence be given from Australia or submissions be made from Australia by remote appearance medium may be made without notice. Except in the case of an application under section 160 of that Act, the application must be accompanied by an affidavit stating—
the nature of the evidence or the submissions:
the place in Australia from which the evidence is to be given or the submissions are to be made:

if it is proposed that evidence be given or submissions be made by audiovisual link, particulars of the audiovisual link facilities available at the courtroom or other place where the court is to sit in New Zealand and at the place where the evidence is to be given or the submissions are to be made in Australia:

if it is proposed that evidence be given or submissions be made by audio link, particulars of the audio link facilities available at the courtroom or other place where the court is to sit in New Zealand and at the place where the evidence is to be given or the submissions are to be made in Australia:
in a case where evidence is proposed to be given, an estimate of the time the evidence will take:
whether issues of character or credibility are likely to be raised:
in a case in which submissions are proposed to be made, an estimate of the time required to make the submissions.

When the court gives a direction under section 168 of the Evidence Act 2006, it must instruct the Registrar to make appropriate arrangements in New Zealand and Australia in accordance with any particular directions that the court may make.
Without limiting subclause (2), the court may—
direct that the evidence be given or the submissions be made at an Australian court or at another place in Australia:
request that an officer of an Australian court or other person approved by the Judge be present to assist in the transmission of evidence or submissions, and in particular to—
introduce witnesses giving evidence or a barrister or solicitor (or both) making submissions:
assist with the administration of oaths:
assist with the implementation of any directions or requests given or made by the Judge hearing the evidence or submissions.
In this rule, evidence includes the related examination of a person giving evidence.

history.history-note: Schedule 2 rule 9.67: replaced, on 11 October 2013, by rule 21 of the High Court (Trans-Tasman Proceedings Act 2010) Amendment Rules 2013 (SR 2013/351).

subpart.heading: Procedure when evidence given by affidavit

para.text: Rules 9.69 to 9.74 apply subject to a direction by the court and to any rule affecting a particular kind of proceeding.
In this subpart, taker means the person before whom an affidavit is sworn or an affirmation is made.
In this rule, the prescribed date means,—
if the parties have agreed under rule 9.55 that evidence be given by affidavit, the date when the agreement was filed:
when these rules provide that the evidence be given by affidavit, the close of pleadings date fixed under rule 7.6.
Within 10 working days after the prescribed date the plaintiff must, subject to rule 19.11, file the plaintiff’s affidavits and serve copies on the other parties.

history.history-note: Schedule 2 rule 9.69(1)﻿(b): amended, on 4 February 2013, by rule 16 of the High Court Amendment Rules (No 2) 2012 (SR 2012/409).

para.text: The defendant must, within 10 working days after service of the plaintiff’s affidavits, file the defendant’s affidavits and serve copies of them on the plaintiff and on any other party.

prov.heading: Time for filing affidavits in reply

para.text: Within 10 working days after service on the plaintiff of the defendant’s affidavits, the plaintiff must file the plaintiff’s affidavits in reply and serve copies of them on the defendant and on any other party.
No affidavit may be read or used until it has been filed.
When an affidavit has been filed, it may be used by any party.
An affidavit may not be taken off the file without the leave of the court.
An affidavit may be read and used in a proceeding only if it complies either with subclause (2) or (3).
A sworn affidavit must be sworn—
in accordance with the Oaths and Declarations Act 1957; and
before a person authorised to administer oaths under that Act or under rule 9.85 or 9.86.
An affirmed affidavit must comply with the Oaths and Declarations Act 1957.

prov.heading: Cross-examination of person who has sworn affidavit

para.text: A party desiring to cross-examine a person who has sworn or affirmed an affidavit on behalf of an opposite party may serve on that opposite party a notice in writing (which may be by letter addressed to the opposite party’s solicitor) requiring the production of that person for cross-examination before the court at the trial.

The notice must be served, and copies of it filed in the court and delivered to all other parties who have taken any step in the proceeding, not less than 3 working days before the day fixed for the trial.
The affidavit of a person who is not produced must not be used as evidence unless the evidence is routine, or there are exceptional circumstances, and in either case the court grants leave.

The party to whom the notice is given is entitled to compel the attendance of the person who has sworn an affidavit for cross-examination in the same way as that party might compel the attendance of a witness to be examined.

If a person having information relevant to a proceeding or an interlocutory application refuses to make an affidavit as to that information, a party may apply for an order directing the person to appear and be examined on oath before the court, or any person the court appoints, as to that information.
The court may—

make any orders the court thinks just for the attendance of that person before the court, or before the person named in the order, for the purpose of being examined, and for the production of any documents specified in the order; and
impose any terms the court thinks just, as to the examination and the costs of and incidental to the application and examination.
An affidavit—
must be expressed in the first person; and
must state the full name, occupation, and place of residence of the person making it; and
must either—
be signed by that person; or
if that person cannot write, have that person’s mark set to it by that person; and
must be confined—
to matters that would be admissible if given in evidence at trial by the deponent; and
if in reply, to matters strictly in reply.
The court—
may refuse to read an affidavit that—
unnecessarily sets forth any argumentative matter or copies of or extracts from documents; or
being in reply, introduces new matter; and
may order that the costs incurred in respect of or occasioned by an affidavit to which paragraph (a) applies be paid by the party filing the affidavit.

The taker must sign the affidavit after the signature of the person making it, and must state the date and place of swearing or affirming the affidavit and the taker’s qualification (in this subpart referred to as the statement by the taker).
If an affidavit has more than 1 page,—

the deponent must initial or set the deponent’s mark on each page (not including the cover sheet) that precedes the page on which the statement by the taker in accordance with subclause (3) appears; and
the taker must initial each of those pages.
This rule does not limit the extent to which subpart 2 of Part 5 applies in respect of affidavits.
Exhibits to an affidavit—
must be marked, in each case, with a distinguishing letter or number; and
must be annexed to the affidavit—
if this is practicable; and
if none of them exceed international size A4; and
must, in each case, be identified by a note made on it and signed by the taker.
Exhibits that are not annexed to the affidavit must, subject to subclause (3), be filed with the affidavit in a separate bundle, which bundle must—
be securely bound; and
include a sheet bearing a proper heading, endorsement, and subscription.

If the size, shape, or nature of an exhibit makes it impracticable to comply with subclause (1)﻿(b) or (2), that exhibit must have firmly affixed to it a sheet bearing a proper heading, endorsement, and subscription.

prov.heading: Interlineation, alteration, or erasure in affidavit

para.text: An affidavit having in the statement by the taker or its contents an interlineation, alteration, or erasure must not, without leave of the court, be read or made use of in a proceeding unless the interlineation or alteration (other than by erasure) is authenticated by the initials of the taker, or, in the case of an erasure, unless the words or figures appearing at the time of taking the affidavit to be written on the erasure are rewritten and signed or initialled in the margin of the affidavit by the taker.

The court may receive any affidavit sworn or affirmed for the purpose of being used in any proceeding, despite any defect by misdescription of parties in the title or statement by the taker, or any other irregularity in its form, and may direct that a note be made on the document that it has been so received.
Every service copy of an affidavit must be legible and, when practicable, include legible copies of all exhibits.

prov.heading: Affidavit may be sworn on Sunday

para.text: An affidavit may be sworn or affirmed on any day, including Sunday.

prov.heading: Affidavits made on behalf of corporation

para.text: A person may make an affidavit on behalf of a corporation or body of persons empowered by law to sue or to be sued (whether in the name of the body or in the name of the holder of an office) if the person—
knows the relevant facts; and
is authorised to make the affidavit.

In an affidavit made by 2 or more persons, the names of each of those persons must be inserted in the statement by the taker. If, however, the affidavit of those persons is sworn (or affirmed) at the same time before the same person, it is sufficient to state that it was sworn (or affirmed) by both (or all) of the persons named above.

prov.heading: Affidavit by blind or illiterate person

para.text: If it appears to the taker that the person making the affidavit is wholly or partially blind, or (whether because of physical handicap or otherwise) is unable to read or has severe difficulty in reading, the taker must certify in the affidavit—
that the affidavit was read and explained by him or her to the person; and
that the person appeared perfectly to understand the affidavit; and
that the person wrote his or her signature or made his or her mark in the presence of the taker.

prov.heading: Authority to take affidavits in New Zealand

para.text: An affidavit may be sworn in New Zealand before a solicitor of the court or a Registrar or a Justice of the Peace.
No affidavit, other than one sworn in respect of a non-contentious proceeding, may be read or used if it was sworn before a solicitor who, at the time of taking it, was acting as—
the solicitor of a party to the proceeding; or
a partner in, or a solicitor employed or engaged by, the firm of the solicitor of a party to the proceeding; or
the agent of the solicitor of a party to the proceeding.
Subclause (2) overrides subclause (1).
In this rule,—
Registrar includes—
a Deputy Registrar of the High Court:
a Registrar of a District Court:
a Deputy Registrar of a District Court
solicitor means a person enrolled as a barrister and solicitor of the High Court.

prov.heading: Authority to take affidavits in places outside New Zealand

para.text: An affidavit may be sworn in a place outside New Zealand before—
a Commissioner of the High Court of New Zealand who has authority in that place; or
a person who is authorised to administer oaths by the law of that place; or
a person who is authorised by a Judge to administer the oath required for the affidavit.
The person administering an oath under subclause (1) must state in the affidavit which qualification that person has.

An affidavit that appears to comply with subclauses (1) and (2) must be taken to have been properly sworn unless the court requires verification by evidence or other means of any matter relating to compliance with either of those subclauses.
Nothing in this rule affects the administering of oaths under the Oaths and Declarations Act 1957.
In rules 9.88 and 9.89, authenticated deposition means a written statement—
made in a place outside New Zealand before a court or a judicial or other authority or person; and
the maker of which is, under the law in force in the place in which the statement is made, liable to punishment if the statement is false; and
that purports to be—
signed by a person holding judicial office or by an official exercising authority under the law in force in the place in which the statement is made; or

sealed with an official or public seal or with the seal of a Minister of State, or with the seal of a department or an official of the government exercising authority in the place in which the statement is made; or

endorsed with or accompanied by a certificate, given by a person having authority under the law in force in the place in which the statement is made to give the certificate, that the statement complies with the requirements of the law in force in that place and that, under that law, the maker of the statement is liable to punishment if the statement is false.
Evidence that may, under these rules, be given by affidavit, may be given in an authenticated deposition.
Rules 9.69 to 9.75 apply, with any necessary modifications, in relation to an authenticated deposition as if the deposition were an affidavit.
Rule 9.88 and this rule do not affect rules 9.17 to 9.29.
The place of trial is the town where the registry of the court in which the statement of defence is to be filed is situated.
Despite subclause (1), if that registry is in Masterton, the place of trial is Wellington.
Despite subclause (1), if that registry is in Tauranga, the court may direct at any time that the place of trial is either Hamilton or Rotorua.
Despite subclauses (1) to (3), the court may at any time order that the proceeding be tried at a place—
that the parties consent to; or
where the proceeding can be more conveniently or more fairly tried.
When the court orders a change of venue, it may direct that all subsequent steps in the proceeding be taken at the place where the trial is to take place.

history.history-note: Schedule 2 rule 10.1: replaced, on 1 January 2011, by rule 15 of the High Court Amendment Rules (No 2) 2010 (SR 2010/394).

subpart.heading: Adjournments, methods of trial, and verdicts

para.text: The court may, before or at the trial, if it is in the interests of justice, postpone or adjourn the trial for any time, to any place, and upon any terms it thinks just.
A proceeding must be tried either before a Judge alone or before a Judge and a jury.
When justice requires, the court may order separate trials of causes of action and it may also direct the sequence of the separate trials and make any supplementary order that is just.
In any proceeding tried before a Judge and a jury, any question as to the existence or accuracy of a record of the court must be determined by the Judge and not by the jury.
If neither party appears when the proceeding is called, the court may order it to be struck out.
The court may order it to be reinstated on good cause shown by either party and on any terms it thinks just.
If the plaintiff appears and the defendant does not, the plaintiff must prove the cause of action so far as the burden of proof lies on the plaintiff.
If the defendant appears but the plaintiff does not, the defendant,—
if the claim is not admitted, is entitled to judgment dismissing the proceeding; and
if there is a counterclaim, must prove it so far as the burden of proof lies on the defendant.

prov.heading: Judgment following non-appearance may be set aside

para.text: Any verdict or judgment obtained when one party does not appear at the trial may be set aside or varied by the court on any terms that are just if there has, or may have been, a miscarriage of justice.
If both the plaintiff and the defendant appear, the plaintiff or any other party that has the right to begin must open the case and offer any evidence in support of it.
When the party who begins has closed that party’s case, the other party must state his or her case and offer any evidence in support of it.
After the evidence has been given, the party who did not begin may address the court generally on the case, and then the other party may address the court in reply.
If, however, the party who did not begin has not offered evidence, the sequence stated in subclause (3) is reversed.
This rule applies subject—
to any directions given under rule 7.2 or 7.8, as the case requires; and
to the provisions of any Act.

history.history-note: Schedule 2 rule 10.10(5)﻿(a): amended, on 11 November 2013, by rule 18 of the High Court Amendment Rules (No 3) 2013 (SR 2013/425).

para.text: When the proceeding is tried with a jury, the Judge must, after the conclusion of counsels' addresses, direct the jury on the evidence given in the case and on any relevant points of law.
The Judge may leave the case to the jury generally to find for either party, or may ask the jury to answer the issues the Judge has settled, and take the verdict of the jury on those issues only.
The jury may, instead of finding a verdict for either party, state the facts as they find them to have been proved.
The statement must be put into writing and signed by the foreman of the jury before the jury is discharged.
The jury may give a verdict for either party, subject to a special case to be stated by the parties.
This rule applies subject to the provisions of any Act.

The court may order that 2 or more proceedings be consolidated on terms it thinks just, or may order them to be tried at the same time or one immediately after another, or may order any of them to be stayed until after the determination of any other of them, if the court is satisfied—
that some common question of law or fact arises in both or all of them; or
that the rights to relief claimed therein are in respect of or arise out of—
the same event; or
the same transaction; or
the same event and the same transaction; or
the same series of events; or
the same series of transactions; or
the same series of events and the same series of transactions; or
that for some other reason it is desirable to make an order under this rule.
Rule 10.12 applies even though—
the relief claimed in the proceedings is not the same; or
1 or more of the proceedings—
is pending in the court in the exercise of its admiralty jurisdiction; or
is brought under the provisions of an Act conferring special jurisdiction on the court.

In rules 10.15 to 10.21, question includes any question or issue in any proceeding, whether of fact or of law or partly of fact and partly of law, and whether raised by pleadings, agreement of parties, or otherwise.
The court may, whether or not the decision will dispose of the proceeding, make orders for—
the decision of any question separately from any other question, before, at, or after any trial or further trial in the proceeding; and
the formulation of the question for decision and, if thought necessary, the statement of a case.
If the court orders the separate decision of a question of law under rule 10.15, it may further order that it be removed into the Court of Appeal.

The parties to a proceeding in which an order is sought or has been made under rule 10.15 may agree that, on any question being decided in the sense specified in the agreement, a specified direction for entry of judgment or a specified order will be made.
On that question being so decided, the court may make the agreed direction or order.
Where an agreement is made under subclause (1) before a case is stated, the terms of the agreement must be set out in the case stated.
When any question is decided under an order made under rule 10.15, the court must, subject to rule 10.19, either—
cause the decision to be recorded; or
direct the entry of an appropriate declaratory judgment or order.

prov.heading: Disposal of proceeding if proceeding substantially affected by decision of question

para.text: This rule applies if a decision of a question under an order made under rule 10.15—
substantially disposes of the proceeding or of the whole or any part of any claim for relief in the proceeding; or
renders unnecessary any trial or further trial in the proceeding or on the whole or any part of any claim for relief in the proceeding.
The court, at the time of deciding the question or at any subsequent time, may, as appropriate,—
dismiss the proceeding or the whole or any part of any claim for relief in the proceeding; or
direct the entry of any judgment; or
make any other order.
A case stated under an order under rule 10.15—
must be divided into paragraphs numbered consecutively; and
must state concisely any facts, and attach any documents that are necessary to enable the court to hear and decide the questions arising on the case stated; and
must state the questions and matters to be decided.

prov.heading: Insufficient case or disputed facts or documents

para.text: If a case stated does not state the facts and documents sufficiently to enable the court to decide the questions arising, or otherwise to hear and determine the questions and matters on the case stated, or in any case in which any relevant fact or document is disputed, the court may,—
with the consent of all parties interested, amend the case stated; or
receive evidence, make findings of fact, and amend the case stated in accordance with the findings of fact of the court.
At the request of the court, the Solicitor-General must appoint counsel to appear and be heard as counsel assisting the court.

history.history-note: Schedule 2 Part 10 subpart 6: inserted, on 1 December 2009, by rule 7 of the High Court Amendment Rules (No 2) 2009 (SR 2009/334).

para.text: In this subpart,—
eligible persons means the persons that the Judge considers should be treated as eligible persons for the purposes of a hearing by video link
judicial location means the courtroom or other place where the Judge hearing a matter by video link is located
remote location means the courtroom or other place, outside the judicial location, where a party, witness, counsel, or other person participating in the hearing of a matter by video link is located
video link means facilities that enable audio and visual communication between persons at a judicial location and persons at a remote location.

history.history-note: Schedule 2 rule 10.23: inserted, on 1 December 2009, by rule 7 of the High Court Amendment Rules (No 2) 2009 (SR 2009/334).

prov.heading: Judge may preside at hearing of certain matters by video link

para.text: For the purposes of section 26IB of the Act, a Judge may, by video link, preside at the hearing of any matter referred to in section 26I of the Act.
A Judge may direct that a matter be heard by video link on the application of 1 or more parties or on the Judge's own initiative.
This rule is subject to rule 10.25.
This rule does not limit or affect the inherent jurisdiction of the court.

history.history-note: Schedule 2 rule 10.24: inserted, on 1 December 2009, by rule 7 of the High Court Amendment Rules (No 2) 2009 (SR 2009/334).

prov.heading: Requirements for hearing by video link

para.text: A Judge must not preside at the hearing of a matter by video link under rule 10.24 unless he or she is satisfied that—
the judicial location and every remote location is equipped with facilities that will—
enable all eligible persons at every remote location to see and hear the Judge and all eligible persons at the judicial location; and
enable the Judge and all eligible persons at the judicial location to see and hear all eligible persons at every remote location; and
enable any document necessary for the purposes of the hearing to be viewed at both the judicial location and every remote location; and
use of a video link is, in all the circumstances, consistent with fairness and the interests of justice.

history.history-note: Schedule 2 rule 10.25: inserted, on 1 December 2009, by rule 7 of the High Court Amendment Rules (No 2) 2009 (SR 2009/334).

para.text: A Judge presiding at the hearing of a matter by video link under rule 10.24 may give directions concerning the procedure for the hearing as he or she thinks fit.
Without limiting subclause (1), the Judge may—
direct that an officer of the court, or other person approved by the court, be present to operate video equipment:
direct that an officer of the court, or other person approved by the court, be present to assist in the hearing, and in particular to—
introduce persons appearing or witnesses giving evidence:
assist with the administration of oaths and affirmations:
assist with the implementation of any directions or requests given or made by the Judge:
direct seating arrangements at a remote location to ensure all participants in the hearing can be seen and heard:
direct when the video link must be operational in relation to his or her own entry to, or rising from, the judicial location.

history.history-note: Schedule 2 rule 10.26: inserted, on 1 December 2009, by rule 7 of the High Court Amendment Rules (No 2) 2009 (SR 2009/334).

para.text: In this Part,—
delivery time has the meaning set out in rule 11.5
judgment includes a decree or order of the court
reasons for judgment means—
the written reasons given by a Judge for his or her decision; or
