A liable party may apply to the court for a stay of enforcement or other relief against the judgment upon the ground that a substantial miscarriage of justice would be likely to result if the judgment were enforced, and the court may give relief on just terms.

prov.heading: Enforcement process may be set aside

para.text: The court may set aside an enforcement process if it is issued contrary to—
any order of the court; or
the agreement of the entitled party; or
good faith.
In this subpart, unless the context otherwise requires,—
employer, in relation to a liable party, includes—
a person by whom a retiring allowance or pension or other payment of a similar nature is payable to the liable party:
the Accident Compensation Corporation in respect of weekly compensation payable to the liable party under the Accident Compensation Act 2001:
the chief executive of the department for the time being responsible for the administration of the Social Security Act 1964 in respect of a benefit payable to the liable party:
a person for whom work is performed under a contract for services
protected earnings amount means an amount specified in an attachment order below which the net earnings or benefit paid to the liable party must not be reduced
salary or wages includes—
a retiring allowance or pension or other payment of a similar nature:
a bonus or an incentive payment:
a payment of commission:
a payment in consideration of work performed under a contract for services:
all payments of weekly compensation made under the Accident Compensation Act 2001 by the Accident Compensation Corporation:
a benefit within the meaning of the Social Security Act 1964.

history.history-note: Schedule 2 rule 17.31 employer paragraph (b): amended, on 3 March 2010, pursuant to section 5(1)﻿(b) of the Accident Compensation Amendment Act 2010 (2010 No 1).
Schedule 2 rule 17.31 salary or wages paragraph (e): amended, on 3 March 2010, pursuant to section 5(1)﻿(b) of the Accident Compensation Amendment Act 2010 (2010 No 1).

para.text: An attachment order directs that money due under a judgment is a charge on any salary or wages that are due and payable by an employer to the liable party.
The charge—
accrues from week to week on the day of the week specified in the attachment order; and
accrues by way of weekly payments of the amount specified in the attachment order; and

attaches to all salary or wages that become due by the employer to the liable party at any time while the attachment order is in force, whether or not the contract of employment or contract for services under which the salary or wages become due existed at the date of the attachment order.

prov.heading: When attachment order may be issued

para.text: If the liable party has been examined under rule 17.15, the court, on the written or oral application of the entitled party, may make an attachment order at any time after judgment is sealed.
An attachment order—
may be made against a person who the court is satisfied is an employer of the liable party:
may be made for a fixed period or until the judgment debt has been fully paid:
must specify the person to whom the amounts to be deducted must be paid:
must specify the protected earnings amount.
Form E 3 must be used.

prov.heading: Attachment order to be served on employer

para.text: A copy of an attachment order must be served on the employer to whom it relates—
personally; or
by leaving it at the employer’s place of residence or business; or
by sending it by post, addressed to the employer at the employer’s place of residence or business.
In the absence of proof to the contrary, any order served by post is deemed to have been served on the sixth working day after the day on which it was posted.
To prove service it is sufficient to prove that the letter was properly addressed and posted.
Every attachment order takes effect when a copy of the order is served on the employer in accordance with this rule.

history.history-note: Schedule 2 rule 17.34(2): amended, on 1 July 2015, by rule 11 of the High Court Amendment Rules 2015 (LI 2015/102).

para.text: The charge under an attachment order is subject to the following charges, adjustments, and deductions (whether the charge was created or the adjustment or deduction was authorised before or after the making of the attachment order under this subpart):
a charge created by an attachment order or deduction notice made under the Family Proceedings Act 1980:
a charge created by an attachment order made under the Summary Proceedings Act 1957:
a deduction notice issued under the Child Support Act 1991:
a deduction notice issued under section 157 of the Tax Administration Act 1994 (as applied by section 193 of the Student Loan Scheme Act 2011):
a deduction from or adjustment to a benefit under section 86 of the Social Security Act 1964.
Subclause (3) applies if the liable party assigns or charges the liable party’s salary or wages before or after the making of the attachment order.
The attachment order has the same effect as it would have if the assignment or charge had not occurred.
Section 84 of the Social Security Act 1964 does not apply to an attachment order under this rule.

history.history-note: Schedule 2 rule 17.35(1)﻿(d): amended, on 1 April 2012, by section 223 of the Student Loan Scheme Act 2011 (2011 No 62).

para.text: The sum of an amount charged under an attachment order and any other amounts described in subclause (2) must not reduce the net earnings or any benefit of the liable party below the protected earnings amount, and if necessary the amount to be deducted under an attachment order must be reduced or cancelled accordingly.
For the purposes of subclause (1), other amounts means the amounts stated in any or all of the following:
an attachment order under another Act; and
a deduction notice made under the Family Proceedings Act 1980 or issued under section 86 or 86A of the Social Security Act 1964.
While an attachment order remains in force and whenever any salary or wages become due and payable by an employer to the liable party, the employer must—
deduct from the salary or wages a sufficient amount to satisfy the charge on the money that has accrued before the day on which the salary or wages becomes due and payable; and
not later than the 20th day of the next month after the month in which the deduction is made, pay the deducted amount to the person specified in the attachment order.
All sums deducted are treated as having been paid by the employer in satisfaction of the salary or wages payable by the employer to the liable party.
All sums deducted are treated as having been paid by the liable party in satisfaction of the liable party’s liability to pay the judgment debt.
The employer must notify a court officer within 5 working days if the liable party leaves or is dismissed from the employer’s employment.

If an employer defaults in paying any money in satisfaction of a charge under an attachment order, that money becomes a debt due by the employer to the entitled party, and may be recovered by the entitled party in any court of competent jurisdiction.
Subclause (1) is subject to rule 17.36.
In this rule,—
employee has the same meaning as in the State Sector Act 1988
State services has the same meaning as in the State Sector Act 1988.
This subpart binds the Crown to the extent of and subject to subclauses (3) and (4).
If the liable party is an employee in the State services, an attachment order may be made against the employer of that employee, and—
the order must be served on the chief executive of the employee’s department or agency or other instrument of the Crown, and also on any officer of the Crown specified in the order; and
the order must be served in accordance with rule 17.34.
When service is effected by post, it is sufficient if the letter is addressed to the person to be served by that person’s official title or any sufficient description.

If the liable party is entitled to a benefit within the meaning of the Social Security Act 1964, an attachment order may be made against the chief executive of the department for the time being responsible for the administration of that Act.
If subclause (5) applies, the order must be served by leaving a copy of the order at, or sending a copy of the order by post to,—
the district office of that department nearest to the liable party’s place of residence; or
an address notified by the chief executive of that department to the chief executive of the Ministry of Justice.

prov.heading: Variation, suspension, and discharge of attachment orders

para.text: An entitled party or a liable party may apply to a Judge for relief under this rule at any time.
If a Judge is satisfied that there is a good reason to do so, he or she may—
vary or suspend the order; or
discharge the order.
The variation, suspension, or discharge takes effect when notice of it is served on the employer in accordance with rule 17.34.
The powers of the Judge under this rule are in addition to the court’s powers under rule 7.49.

A charging order charges the estate, right, title, or interest of the liable party in the property described in the order with payment of the amount for which the entitled party may obtain or has obtained judgment.
A charging order may be in form E 4, form E 5, or form E 6.
Leave to issue a charging order before judgment may be granted only on proof that the liable party, with intent to defeat either his or her creditors or the entitled party or both,—
is removing, concealing, or disposing of the liable party’s property; or
is absent from or about to leave New Zealand.

prov.heading: Issue of charging order without leave after judgment

para.text: After judgment is sealed, the entitled party may issue a charging order without leave.

prov.heading: Charging order where amount involved small

para.text: If the amount involved is so small that the issue of a charging order is vexatious or worthless, the court may—
refuse the application for a charging order; or
if the charging order has been issued (whether as of right or on application), revoke the charging order.

prov.heading: Application for relief by persons prejudicially affected

para.text: At any time, a person alleging that he or she is prejudicially affected by a charging order may apply to the court for relief.
The court may—
vary or rescind the order; or
cancel the registration or modify the effect of registration of any order affecting land.
The powers of the court under this rule are in addition to its powers under rule 7.49.

prov.heading: Claim of third party on property charged

para.text: For the purposes of this rule, interested third party means a person other than the entitled party or liable party who allegedly—
owns the charged property; or
has a lien, charge, or other claim on the charged property.
The court may order an interested third party to attend the court and state the nature and details of the third party’s interest in the charged property.
An interested third party may attend and state the nature and particulars of that party’s claim to the court without the court’s leave at the hearing of—
an application to make the charging order final:
an application to set aside or vary the charging order.
An interested third party must give 24 hours’ notice to the court and all affected parties of an intention to attend the court under subclause (3).

prov.heading: Apportionment when more than 1 charging order

para.text: Subclause (2) applies if more than 1 charging order has been issued against the same liable party.

The court may, on the application of the liable party or any other person claiming to be affected, determine how much or what part of the relevant property is for the separate use of each entitled party who has obtained a charging order.

prov.heading: Charging order for land final when issued

para.text: A charging order may charge an estate, right, title, or interest in possession, remainder, reversion, or expectancy (whether vested or contingent) in any land held in the liable party’s own name.
A charging order issued under this rule is a final charging order when it is issued.

prov.heading: Registration of charging order under Land Transfer Act 1952

para.text: A final charging order in respect of land that is under the Land Transfer Act 1952 must be registered under that Act against the land’s certificate of title.
The charging order must sufficiently refer to the affected land so as to identify that land by—
a description of the land; or
a reference to a certificate of title or other instrument containing a description of the land.

Unless the land is the whole of the land comprised in a certificate or certificates of title, or is shown separately on a plan deposited under the Land Transfer Act 1952, the charging order must have drawn on it or annexed to it a plan of the land showing its extent, boundaries, and relative position.

The entitled party must deposit a duplicate of the charging order with the District Land Registrar (unless that Registrar has dispensed with the production of duplicate instruments in accordance with the Land Transfer Act 1952).

prov.heading: Registration of charging order not under Land Transfer Act 1952

para.text: A final charging order in respect of land that is not under the Land Transfer Act 1952 must be registered with the district Registrar of Deeds under the Deeds Registration Act 1908 or otherwise in accordance with the current law about the registration of deeds.
The charging order must sufficiently refer to the affected land so as to identify that land by—
a description of the land; or
a reference to a Crown grant or other instrument containing a description of the land.
The charging order must have drawn on it or annexed to it a plan of the land showing its extent, boundaries, and relative position.

prov.heading: Sale before registration of charging order

para.text: An unregistered charging order has no effect against a purchaser for valuable consideration.

prov.heading: Discharge of land from charging order

para.text: Land subject to a final charging order is discharged from that order on registration with the District Land Registrar or Registrar of Deeds of—
a memorandum of satisfaction of the judgment in the proceeding in which the charging order has been issued or other sufficient evidence of satisfaction; or
an order of the court to the effect that the land is discharged from the charging order; or
the consent of the person who registered the charging order to the discharge of the land from the charging order.

prov.heading: Lapse of charging order after 2 years

para.text: A charging order no longer binds the land affected and is treated as discharged after 2 years from the date of the charging order unless it is extended under subclause (2).
The court may within that period, if it thinks just, extend the effect of a charging order for any necessary period.
Subclause (1) does not apply if the charging order has led to a sale order, and a person registers any of the following in relation to the land under that sale order:
an instrument of transfer:
a deed of conveyance:
an assignment.
A charging order may charge all personal property, including—
debts payable by or accruing due from the Crown to the liable party that are not excepted by section 26 of the Crown Proceedings Act 1950:
a debt or sum of money due or accruing due to the liable party, including money—
due or accruing due to the liable party by a public body; or
standing to the credit of the liable party in a proceeding or interlocutory application; or
standing to the credit of the liable party in the possession of a Sheriff or court officer:
the right or interest of the liable party in a partnership:
shares held by the liable party in any company that—
is incorporated in New Zealand; or
has a registry in New Zealand in which transfers of shares may be registered:

the estate, right, or interest in possession, remainder, reversion, or expectancy (whether vested or contingent) in any land, or in any money, shares, or other personal property, held under or because of any express or implied trust for the liable party.

prov.heading: Interim charging order in first instance

para.text: A charging order under rule 17.53—
is a limited charging order until the court discharges or finalises it in accordance with these rules; and
is called an interim charging order in this rule and in rules 17.55 to 17.60.
An interim charging order must be served—
on the person it is intended to affect; or
on any person the court directs, if money is—
due by the Crown or a public body; or
standing to the credit of a liable party in a proceeding or interlocutory application.
If an interim charging order is intended to affect an estate, right, or interest in land under or because of any trust,—
that interim charging order may also be registered against the land; or
a caveat may be lodged against the land in respect of the interim charging order.
A person served with an interim charging order may not, except under rules 17.56 to 17.61 or with the leave of the court,—
pay over any debt, income, interest, dividends, bonus, profits, or other money due or accruing due to the liable party named in the interim charging order; or

make, concur in making, or permit any conveyance, transfer, assignment, or disposition of any estate, right, or interest, or of any share in a partnership or company, of the liable party named in the interim charging order.

prov.heading: Liability of persons breaching interim charging order

para.text: If a person who has been served with an interim charging order breaches rule 17.55, the court may order that person to pay the entitled person either of the following:
the amount of the money paid or the value of the property disposed of in breach of that rule; or
a sufficient part of the money paid or the value of the property disposed of in breach of that rule to satisfy any judgment the entitled party may obtain or may have obtained in the proceeding.
The court’s orders under subclause (1) may be in addition to or instead of a penalty that may be imposed by or under another rule.

prov.heading: Money may be paid into court

para.text: A person served with an interim charging order may pay the money affected by the order into court.
The money paid into court must be paid out in accordance with the result of the proceeding or an order of the court.

prov.heading: Court may order sale of property affected

para.text: On an application by the entitled party or by the person affected by the order, the court may do 1 or more of the following:
order that any property affected be sold:
give directions about the sale as the court thinks just:
order that the net proceeds of the sale be paid into court, to be paid out later in accordance with the result of the proceeding or an order of the court.
The court may act under subclause (1) when making an interim charging order or at any later time before judgment.

prov.heading: Application to make final charging order after judgment

para.text: The entitled party may apply to the court to have an interim charging order made final at any time after judgment is sealed.
The court may make orders and give directions for the disposal of money paid into court under rule 17.57 or 17.58.

prov.heading: Execution after charging order made final

para.text: After a charging order has been made final, the entitled party may do either or both of the following:
if a person is affected by an interim charging order because he or she owes any money due or accruing due to the liable party,—
issue a sale order under rules 17.62 to 17.82 against that person’s property; and
execute the sale order as if judgment had been sealed by the liable party against that person:
sell any property referred to in paragraphs (c) to (e) of rule 17.53 under a sale order in the same way (as nearly as possible) as a sale of land under rules 17.62 to 17.82.

prov.heading: Discharge of person served with order

para.text: A person served with a final charging order who pays money under it to a court officer (whether because of an enforcement process or otherwise) is discharged from that person’s obligation to the liable party to the extent of the amount paid.
Subclause (1) applies even if the court sets aside or reverses—
the final charging order; or
the judgment in the proceeding in which the final charging order was obtained.
A sale order authorises and requires an enforcing officer to seize all the liable party’s personal property except—
necessary tools of trade to a value not exceeding $5,000; and
necessary household furniture and effects to a value not exceeding $10,000 (necessary household furniture and effects includes the clothes of the liable party and his or her family).
An enforcing officer must take the actions described in subclause (3) if money seized under a sale order is not enough to—
discharge any claims which by law are entitled to be paid in priority to the entitled party’s claim; and
pay the costs and expenses of executing the order; and
satisfy the amount of the judgment and interest payable to the entitled party.
In the situation described in subclause (2), an enforcing officer must—
receive and recover the sum or sums—
payable under any cheques, bills of exchange, and promissory notes; or
secured by bonds or other securities for money; and

sell, in accordance with rules 17.63 to 17.82, the seized chattels and the liable party’s estate, right, title, or interest in any land (whether it is in possession, remainder, reversion, or expectancy).
A sale order may be in form E 7.

prov.heading: When sale order may be issued

para.text: An entitled party may issue a sale order at any time after judgment for a sum of money is sealed.

prov.heading: Execution for less than full amount of judgment

para.text: An entitled party must endorse the sale order with the amount claimed.
The amount claimed must reflect any of the following that apply:
money paid on account of the judgment:
the entitled party’s wish to waive—
any part of the money due on account of the judgment; or
payment of the entitled party’s costs or any part of those costs:
that the judgment has been given for a larger amount than is due.

If the amount due under a judgment is less than the amount of the judgment and the entitled party has not endorsed that on the sale order as required by this rule, the court may set aside or vary the order and make whatever restitutionary or incidental orders are thought just.

prov.heading: Recovery of money owing on cheques and other securities

para.text: If money seized under a sale order is not the full amount required by the sale order, the enforcing officer may seize any of the following as security for the balance of the full amount:
cheques:
bills of exchange:
promissory notes:
bonds:
other securities for money.
The officer may sue the issuer of the security in the officer’s own name for the sum or sums secured by it in accordance with the terms of the particular security seized.
The officer need not sue under subclause (2) unless the entitled party enters into a bond with 2 sufficient guarantors that indemnifies the officer against—
all costs and expenses of suing; and
all costs and expenses to which the officer may become liable as a result of the suit.
The expenses of the bond referred to in subclause (3) must be deducted out of any money recovered in the proceeding.

prov.heading: Discharge of person paying on cheque or other security

para.text: A person liable to the liable party under a security seized under rule 17.65 who pays money under the security to a court officer (whether because of an enforcement process or otherwise) is discharged from liability to the liable party to the extent of the amount paid.
The order in which an enforcing officer must apply the proceeds of the sale order is—
discharging all claims that have priority over the entitled party’s claim:
paying the costs and expenses of executing the sale order:
paying the entitled party a sufficient sum to satisfy the amount required by the sale order:
paying any surplus to the liable party.
An enforcing officer need not seize land before selling the land.
An enforcing officer must move chattels seized under a sale order to an appropriate selling place as soon as possible.
The liable party may consent in writing to the chattels—
remaining in the place where they were seized; and
being kept in the custody of a person the officer considers appropriate; and
being sold in that place.
Subclause (2) is an exception to subclause (1).
An enforcing officer must sell seized chattels in the place he or she considers best.
With the written consent of the liable party, the officer may—
sell chattels at the place of seizure; and
sell land to be sold on the land itself.
An enforcing officer must give notice of the sale of seized chattels in whichever newspaper or newspapers the officer considers sufficient.
The notice must be first published,—
for a land sale, at least 15 working days before the date of the intended sale:
for any other sale, at least 5 working days before the date of the intended sale.
The notice may be republished in the same or other newspaper or newspapers in the way and to the extent the officer considers sufficient.
The notice—
must contain the information specified in rule 17.73; and
must be in the form and give the particulars the officer considers sufficient.

prov.heading: Service of notice of sale on liable party

para.text: At least 7 working days before the sale, an enforcing officer must serve a copy of the notice referred to in rule 17.71 on the liable party—
at the liable party’s address for service; or
if the liable party has not filed an address for service, at the liable party’s last known residential address.
The notice referred to in rule 17.71—
must state that the sale is made on behalf of the entitled party; and
must specify—
the chattels, or the right or interest in the chattels, or the land, or the estate, right, title, or interest in the land, intended to be sold; and
the name of the enforcing officer; and
the name of the solicitor (if any) for the entitled party.
All sales under a sale order must be—
by public auction on terms and conditions approved by the Registrar; or
by private treaty—
with the parties’ consent; or
by order of the court made on the application of either party.
An enforcing officer may choose whether to sell property seized under a sale order in 1 lot or in several lots.
Unless the court directs otherwise, all sales—
must be for cash on delivery, assignment, or transfer; and
must be of the estate, right, title, or interest only of the liable party in the chattels or land put up for sale.

prov.heading: Powers of enforcing officer in relation to sale by auction

para.text: An enforcing officer—
may sell property seized under a sale order by public auction without an auctioneer’s licence (despite anything in any Act to the contrary); and
may place a reserve on the property; and
may put the property up for sale as often as required until it is sold.

prov.heading: Power of enforcing officer to seize title deeds

para.text: The enforcing officer may require the liable party—
to provide (if they are in the liable party’s possession) the certificate of title and any title deeds for land that is to be sold; and
to disclose—
the name of any person who has possession of the certificate of title and any title deeds for land that is to be sold; and
the address where those documents are kept.
If the person who possesses the documents referred to in subclause (1) refuses to give them to the officer, the officer may seize those documents.
The officer may give copies of the certificate of title and any title deeds to an intending purchaser.

prov.heading: Order of sale of land and chattels

para.text: An enforcing officer must sell chattels first if both land and chattels were seized from a liable party under the same sale order unless another sequence is—
preferred by the liable party; or
directed by the court.
Despite any preferences of the liable party, the court may direct under subclause (1)﻿(b) that the land be sold—
before the chattels; or
at the same time as a specified chattel or a specified class of chattels.

If the proceeds of the sale of the chattels or of the land or of the land and some of the chattels are insufficient to satisfy the amount required by the sale order, the enforcing officer must sell the remaining seized property.

prov.heading: Power of liable party or mortgagee to give directions concerning sale of land

para.text: A liable party whose interest in land is to be sold or a mortgagee of that interest may by notice require that any specified portions of the land that may lawfully be sold separately be sold first.
A notice under subclause (1) must be—
in writing; and
delivered to an enforcing officer at least 10 working days before the date of the sale.
If the liable party and a mortgagee deliver conflicting requirements under subclause (1), the mortgagee’s requirement prevails.
An enforcing officer must sell the specified portions first in accordance with a notice under subclause (1) or any prevailing mortgagee’s requirement under subclause (3).
If the sum realised by the sale of the specified portions is sufficient to satisfy the execution, interest, costs, and expenses, the officer may not sell any other part of the land.
Unless subclause (5) applies, the officer must, after selling the specified portions, proceed with the sale of the remainder.
A valid instrument of transfer, deed of conveyance, or assignment to the purchaser of the estate, right, title, or interest of the liable party in any land or chattels sold—
must be prepared by the purchaser at the purchaser’s own expense; and
must be left for approval with the enforcing officer 4 working days before it is to be executed.
The officer must (if required by the purchaser) execute the instrument if and when the officer approves it.
The instrument, when executed by the officer,—
is equally effective for all purposes as if it had been executed by the liable party; and
is prima facie evidence of—
the existence of a valid judgment and sale order supporting the seizure by the officer; and
all necessary notices having been given and published; and
a valid seizure; and
a sale having taken place according to law.
A possession order authorises and requires an enforcing officer to deliver possession of the land or chattels described in the order to the person named in the order.
For the purpose described in subclause (1), the officer may—
eject any other person from land; or
seize and take possession of the chattels.
A possession order may be in form E 8.

prov.heading: When possession order may be issued

para.text: If a judgment orders a party to deliver possession of land or chattels to another party, that other party may issue a possession order.
If a judgment orders a party to pay a sum of money and to deliver possession of land or chattels to another party, that other party may issue a sale and possession order.

An arrest order authorises and requires an enforcing officer to arrest any person named in the order and to bring that person before the court at the time and place specified in the order, and until then, to keep the person in safe custody.
An arrest order may be in form E 9.
In this subpart, an original court order means, whether or not the order is in a judgment, a court order to do or abstain from doing something that is not paying a sum of money.

If a party has been served with an original court order but does not comply, a Judge may issue an order arresting the non-complying party on the application of a party entitled to the benefit of that order.

prov.heading: Power to commit to prison for disobedience

para.text: A court may commit to prison a party brought before the court on an arrest order unless the party complies with the original court order.
A court may commit a party to prison under subclause (1) for a term that—
the court considers necessary; and
is allowed by law.
A sequestration order authorises and requires the sequestrator to enter and take possession of all the real and personal property of the party against whom it is directed.
The sequestrator must obtain the rents and profits from the property until—
the party clears the party’s contempt of court in the way specified in the order; or
the court orders otherwise.
A sequestration order may be in form E 10.

If a party has been served with an original court order or an order to pay money into court but does not comply, the court may issue a sequestration order against the property of the non-complying party.
The court can issue a sequestration order under subclause (1) only on notice to the non-complying party.
The court must appoint a sequestrator of the property and the provisions of rules 7.61 to 7.67 apply, with all necessary modifications, as if the sequestrator were a receiver.

subpart.heading: Absconding debtors and imprisonment for debt

para.text: The plaintiff may make an application without notice for an order to arrest and imprison a defendant under section 55 of the Act.
The defendant may at any time before or after arrest apply to the court to rescind or vary the order or to be discharged from custody, or for other relief.
The court may make any order that is just on an application under subclause (2).

prov.heading: Process for order to arrest and imprison defendant

para.text: An order to arrest and imprison a defendant under section 55 of the Act must be—
in form E 11; or
if section 55(3) of the Act applies, in form E 12.
Concurrent orders may be issued for arrest in different places.
The order must be endorsed with the address for service of the plaintiff before it is delivered to the Sheriff.
The Sheriff or other enforcing officer must endorse the actual date of the arrest on the order within 2 working days after the arrest.
The security to be given by a defendant to discharge an order to arrest and imprison him or her under section 55 of the Act may be—
a deposit in court of the amount mentioned in the order; or
a bond to the plaintiff by the defendant and 2 sufficient sureties; or
with the plaintiff’s consent, any other form of security.

Within 4 working days of receiving details of the names and addresses of the proposed sureties and the form of the proposed bond, the plaintiff may give a notice of objection to the sureties and form of bond, with details of the reasons for objection.
If the plaintiff gives a notice under subclause (2), the Registrar must determine the sufficiency of the security, and the Registrar has the power to award the costs of the reference to either party.
The court may, at any time, order—
that the whole or part of a sum of money paid or secured under rule 17.90 be paid to the plaintiff; or
that any security given under rule 17.90 by the defendant be enforced.
An enforcing officer must give a receipt for the payment into court of the amount required by an order under rule 17.91.
The plaintiff or the plaintiff’s solicitor must give a certificate of receipt of the bond or other security required by an order under rule 17.91.
The defendant is entitled to be discharged out of prison when a receipt or certificate under this rule is given to the Sheriff.

part.heading: Applications in equity and under statutes

para.text: This Part applies to the following types of proceedings:
proceedings in which the relief claimed is wholly within the equitable jurisdiction of the court, such as—

the determination of a claim to an entitlement as beneficiary under a will or trust or on the intestacy of a deceased person, or as creditor of a deceased person, whether the claim is made by the person claiming to be entitled or by that person’s assignee or successor:
the ascertainment of a class of creditors, beneficiaries under a will, or persons entitled on the intestacy of a deceased person, or of beneficiaries under a trust:
the giving of particular accounts by executors, administrators, or trustees:
the payment into court of money held by executors, administrators, or trustees:
the giving of directions to persons in their capacity as executors, administrators, trustees, or beneficiaries to do or abstain from doing a particular act:
the approval of a sale, purchase, compromise, or other transaction by executors, administrators, or trustees:
the carrying-on of a business authorised to be carried on by any deed or instrument creating a trust or by the court:
the interpretation of a deed or instrument creating a trust:
the determination of a question that arises in the administration of an estate or trust or whose determination is necessary or desirable to protect the executors, administrators, or trustees:
proceedings in which the relief is claimed solely under the following enactments:
the Care of Children Act 2004:
the Charitable Trusts Act 1957:
the Companies Act 1993 (not being a proceeding properly brought under Part 19 or 31 of these rules):
the Corporations (Investigation and Management) Act 1989:
the Declaratory Judgments Act 1908:
the Family Protection Act 1955:
the Incorporated Societies Act 1908:
the Industrial and Provident Societies Act 1908:
the Insolvency Act 2006 and the Insolvency (Cross-border) Act 2006:
sections 140, 143, 144, 145, 145A, and 148 of the Land Transfer Act 1952 (which relate to caveats):
the Law Reform (Testamentary Promises) Act 1949:
the Mental Health (Compulsory Assessment and Treatment) Act 1992:
the Trustee Act 1956:
any repealed enactment to which Part 4 of the High Court Rules applied immediately before the commencement of these rules if the enactment continues to apply to the plaintiff:
any proceeding by a party to, or an assignee of, a contract for the sale of the freehold or leasehold in any land, for relief in respect of—
any requisitions or objections; or
any claim for compensation; or
any other question arising out of or connected with the contract (not being a question affecting the existence or validity of the contract):
any proceeding by a person affected by a mortgage or charge (whether legal or equitable) of an interest in land for the purpose of determining—
the person’s rights or obligations under the mortgage or charge; or
the exercise or purported or threatened exercise of any right or power alleged to arise out of the mortgage or charge:
any other proceeding to which the court directs that this Part is to apply.

prov.heading: Limited application of this Part to proceedings under Property (Relationships) Act 1976

para.text: Rule 18.14 (which relates to joinder of claims and consolidation) and rule 18.15 (which relates to evidence) apply to proceedings transferred to the court by order of a Family Court Judge under section 22(3) of the Property (Relationships) Act 1976, but no other rule in this Part applies to proceedings under that Act.

prov.heading: This Part subject to rules under other Acts

para.text: The application of this Part to a proceeding brought under an Act is subject to any rules in force under that Act.
A proceeding under this Part must be—
commenced by statement of claim; and
accompanied by an application for directions as to service and representation under rule 18.7.

The application of this Part to a proceeding does not prevent the commencement of that proceeding by originating application if it is eligible to be so commenced under Part 19, in which event this Part does not apply.

history.history-note: Schedule 2 rule 18.4(1)﻿(b): replaced, on 11 November 2013, by rule 22(1) of the High Court Amendment Rules (No 3) 2013 (SR 2013/425).
Schedule 2 rule 18.4(3): repealed, on 11 November 2013, by rule 22(2) of the High Court Amendment Rules (No 3) 2013 (SR 2013/425).

subpart.heading: Special provisions concerning pleadings, directions, and affidavits

prov.heading: Naming of defendants in cases involving deceased estates or trusts

para.text: This rule applies to a proceeding that—
involves a deceased estate or a trust; and
is not commenced by the personal representative of the deceased person or the trustee of the trust.
The only defendant that may be named in the statement of claim is the personal representative or the trustee.

In proceedings under the Family Protection Act 1955 or the Law Reform (Testamentary Promises) Act 1949, the only defendant that may be named in the statement of claim is the personal representative of the deceased person against whose estate the claim is brought.

prov.heading: Persons served by direction of court need not be named as defendant

para.text: A person who becomes a defendant to a proceeding by being served under a direction of the court need not be named as defendant.

prov.heading: Applications for directions as to service

para.text: This rule applies when—
the law requires the making of an application for directions as to service; or
the plaintiff is in doubt regarding the persons on whom the statement of claim should be served; or
an order is sought that any person represent any other person or class of persons who should be served; or
the proceeding is under the Companies Act 1993 and is not a proceeding in the liquidation of a company or an application to set aside a statutory demand under section 290 of that Act; or
the court directs that the plaintiff should apply to the court under this rule.
The plaintiff must apply to the court without notice for directions as to service and for any orders for representation that may be required.

In support of the application, the plaintiff must provide (by affidavit or otherwise) the information that may be necessary to enable the court to decide what persons or classes of persons are interested in, or may be adversely affected by, the relief sought by the plaintiff and by what means the interests of each such person or class of persons may be adequately represented.
In the case of claims under the Family Protection Act 1955 or the Law Reform (Testamentary Promises) Act 1949, the information required by subclause (3) includes—
the date of death of the deceased and the date of grant of probate or letters of administration:
whether the deceased died testate or intestate, and, if testate, a copy of his or her last will with codicils (if any):
the value of the estate, so far as it is known to the plaintiff:
the names, addresses, occupations, and ages of the beneficiaries under the will or persons entitled on intestacy, as the case may be:
the names, addresses, occupations, and ages of the persons of each class entitled to claim under the Family Protection Act 1955:
any other information that is relevant.
The application must specify the directions sought and be accompanied by a memorandum by the plaintiff’s solicitor or counsel stating why the directions are sought.

history.history-note: Schedule 2 rule 18.7(1)﻿(d): amended, on 1 February 2012, by rule 6 of the High Court Amendment Rules (No 2) 2011 (SR 2011/351).

prov.heading: Orders giving directions as to service

para.text: On an application under rule 18.7, the Judge may make any orders for service or representation that the Judge thinks just.

If, in a proceeding involving an incapacitated person or minor, the Judge considers it is not necessary to appoint a litigation guardian, the Judge may make orders with regard to the representation of that person, without the appointment of a litigation guardian under rule 4.35.
The effect of every order for directions as to service or for representation made under this rule must be set out in the notice of proceeding in accordance with rule 5.23.
This rule applies to a statement of claim that need not be served because of an enactment or a direction of a Judge.

The facts alleged in the statement of claim must be verified by or on behalf of the plaintiff by an affidavit (which may be appended to the statement of claim or filed separately) stating that, so far as they relate to matters within the personal knowledge of the person making the affidavit, they are true, and, so far as they relate to matters not within that person’s personal knowledge, the person believes them to be true.
Despite subclause (2), the Judge may require any fact not within the personal knowledge of the person to be proved by the affidavit of a person who has such personal knowledge.

prov.heading: Time for serving claimant’s affidavit in proceedings under Family Protection Act 1955

para.text: A claimant against the estate of a deceased person under the Family Protection Act 1955 must, at the time of serving his or her statement of claim, serve his or her own affidavit in support of his or her statement of claim.

prov.heading: Time for serving affidavit in support of appearance

para.text: If a defendant in any proceeding to which this Part applies files an appearance in lieu of a statement of defence, the defendant may, at the time of serving the defendant’s appearance, without leave, and at any time afterwards with leave of the court, serve the defendant’s affidavits in support of any matters referred to in the appearance.
These rules apply to affidavits filed under subclause (1) as though they were affidavits filed by a plaintiff in support of a statement of claim.

prov.heading: Statement of defence to be filed

para.text: No affidavit may be filed by a defendant in opposition to the claim of the plaintiff or of any claimant under rule 18.13 unless the defendant has filed and served a statement of defence to the claim or an appearance.
Affidavits filed by any party after a statement of defence or appearance has been filed must be confined to matters put in issue by pleadings or by the appearance.
Subclause (1) is subject to rule 18.11.

subpart.heading: Multiple claims, joinders, and consolidations of claims

prov.heading: Joining in proceedings under Family Protection Act 1955 and Law Reform (Testamentary Promises) Act 1949

para.text: A person who is a defendant in a proceeding under the Family Protection Act 1955 or the Law Reform (Testamentary Promises) Act 1949 (party A) must make any claim against the same estate by filing a statement of claim in the proceeding, and, when that statement of claim is filed, these rules apply as if—
party A were a plaintiff; and
the plaintiff were a defendant.

When a statement of claim is filed under subclause (1), it is not necessary for party A to apply for directions for service or to file or serve a notice of proceeding but party A must serve party A’s statement of claim and affidavits—
on the personal representative; and
on the plaintiff; and
on all other persons (except party A) whom the plaintiff has been directed to serve.

A person, who has not been directed to be served in a proceeding under the Acts specified in subclause (1), must make any claim under those Acts against the same estate by filing a statement of claim in the proceeding, and, when that statement of claim is filed, subclauses (1) and (2) apply as if that person were party A.
Claims under the Family Protection Act 1955 and the Law Reform (Testamentary Promises) Act 1949 may be joined in 1 statement of claim, whether or not the claims are made in the alternative.
Separate proceedings against the estate of the same deceased person may be consolidated under rules 10.12 and 10.13 if they are—
proceedings under the Family Protection Act 1955; or
proceedings under the Law Reform (Testamentary Promises) Act 1949; or
proceedings under the Property (Relationships) Act 1976, transferred to the court by order of a Family Court Judge under section 22(3) of that Act.

prov.label: 18.14A
prov.heading: Procedure under section 174 of Companies Act 1993

para.text: In a proceeding under section 174 of the Companies Act 1993,—
the statement of claim must be in form C 2; and
the notice of proceeding must be in form C 3; and
an appearance in support or in opposition must be in form C 9.

Subpart 2 of Part 7, which relates to interlocutory applications, applies to applications to the court that relate to a company in respect of which an application under section 174 of the Companies Act 1993 is pending.

history.history-note: Schedule 2 rule 18.14A: replaced, on 4 February 2013, by rule 22 of the High Court Amendment Rules (No 2) 2012 (SR 2012/409).

prov.label: 18.14B
prov.heading: Service of order made under section 174 of Companies Act 1993

para.text: When an order is made under section 174 of the Companies Act 1993, a registry copy of the order must, unless the court otherwise orders, be served by the plaintiff on—
the defendant company in accordance with the Companies Act 1993; and
the Registrar of Companies.
If the order involves an alteration of the constitution of the company, the Companies Act 1993 applies as the court directs.

history.history-note: Schedule 2 rule 18.14B: inserted, on 1 February 2012, by rule 7 of the High Court Amendment Rules (No 2) 2011 (SR 2011/351).

prov.heading: Evidence generally by agreed statement of facts or affidavit

para.text: Unless a Judge otherwise directs, evidence in a proceeding to which this Part applies must be given—
by means of an agreed statement of facts in accordance with rule 9.57; or
by affidavit in accordance with rules 9.72 to 9.89.
Unless a Judge otherwise directs, evidence must be given orally in a proceeding—
under the Law Reform (Testamentary Promises) Act 1949:
in which relief by way of specific performance is sought.
Subclause (1) applies to a proceeding in respect of which a direction has been given under subclause (2).

subpart.heading: Proceedings eligible to be commenced by originating application

para.text: In these rules, originating application means an application made in accordance with this Part.
Applications to the court under the following enactments must be made by originating application:
the Arbitration Act 1996 (other than article 35 of Schedule 1 and clause 5 of Schedule 2 of that Act):
section 21(1)﻿(a) and (b) and Parts 3, 4, and 5 of the Charitable Trusts Act 1957:
sections 34, 41, 95, 97, and 126 of the Coroners Act 2006:
sections 58 and 59 of the Corporations (Investigation and Management) Act 1989:
sections 32 and 33 of the Cultural Property (Protection in Armed Conflict) Act 2012:
section 166E of the Customs and Excise Act 1996:
section 43(6) of the District Courts Act 1947:
the Habeas Corpus Act 2001:
section 23A of the Incorporated Societies Act 1908:
section 10A of the Industrial and Provident Societies Act 1908:
section 56 of the Judicature Act 1908:
sections 132, 133, 140, 143, 145, 145A, 148, and 217 of the Land Transfer Act 1952:
sections 30, 37, 52, 166, 180, and 182 of the Lawyers and Conveyancers Act 2006:
section 9A(3) of the Law Reform Act 1936:
sections 100 and 111 of the Marine and Coastal Area (Takutai Moana) Act 2011:
section 12(1)﻿(a) of the Minors’ Contracts Act 1969:
section 112 of the Patents Act 2013 (subject to Part 22 of these rules):
sections 128, 131, 167, 168, 179, 181, 182, and 186 of the Personal Property Securities Act 1999:
the Criminal Proceeds (Recovery) Act 2009:
sections 126, 136, 244, 248, 253, 254, 258, 261, and 357 of the Property Law Act 2007:
the Protection of Personal and Property Rights Act 1988:
the Reciprocal Enforcement of Judgments Act 1934:
section 44C(2) and (8) of the Securities Act 1978:
section 47E of the Terrorism Suppression Act 2002:
section 76 of the Trustee Act 1956:
section 14 or 31 of the Wills Act 2007:
any repealed enactment if—
the application under that enactment could have been made by originating application immediately before the commencement of these rules; and
the enactment continues to apply to the applicant:

history.history-note: Schedule 2 rule 19.2(ea): inserted, on 1 July 2013, by rule 4 of the High Court (Cultural Property (Protection in Armed Conflict) Act 2012) Amendment Rules 2013 (SR 2013/196).
Schedule 2 rule 19.2(na): inserted, on 3 November 2011, by rule 4 of the High Court Amendment Rules 2011 (SR 2011/350).
